sp.p: That had been Single indeed: why? be they not the same persons in this, as they would haue been in those? and is it not an object of more State, to behold the Scene full, and relieu'd with varietie of Speakers to the end, than to see a vast emptie stage, and the Actors come in (one by one) as if they were dropt down with a feather into the eie of the Audience?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Nay, you are better traded with these things than I, and therefore I'le subscribe to your judgement; mary you shall giue me leaue to make objections.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O what else? it's the speciall intent of the Author you should do so: for thereby others (that are present) may as well be satisfied, who happily would object the same you doe.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: So sir, but when appeares Macilente againe?

div.stage: Enter Macilente, Deliro, Fido, with hearbs and persumes.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Mary he staies but till our silence giue him leaue: here he comes, and with him Signior Deliro a merchant, at whose house he is come to sojourne: Make your owne obscruation now; onely transferre your thoughts to the Cittie with the Scene; where, suppose they speake.

div.head: SCENA TERTIA.

sp.speaker: Deliro.
sp.l: I'le tell you by and by sir.
Welcome (good Macilente) to my house,
To sojourne euen for euer; if my best
In cates, and euerie sort of good intreatie
May mooue you stay with me.

div.stage: Deliro turnes to his boy, and falls a strowing of flowers.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I thanke you sir:
And yet the muffled Fates (had it pleas'd them)
Might haue suppli'd me from their owne full store
Without this word (I thanke you) to a foole.
I see no reason why that Dog (call'd Chaunce)
Should fawne vpon this fellow more than me:
I am a man, and I haue Limmes, Flesh, Blood,
Bones, Sinewes, and a Soule as well as he:
My parts are euery way as good as his,
If I said better? why I did not lie,
Nath'lesse his wealth (but nodding on my wants)
Must make me bow, and crie: I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Dispatch, take heed your mistresse see you not.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Nay gentle friend be merrie, raise your lookes
Out of your bosome, I protest (by heauen)
You are the man most welcome in the world.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I thanke you Sir, I know my cue I thinke.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Where will you haue 'hem burne Sir?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Here good Fido:
What? she did not see thee?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: That's well:
Strew, strew, good Fido, the freshest flowers, so.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What meanes this Signior Deliro?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Cast in more Frankincence, yet more, well said.
O Macilente, I haue such a wife,
So passing faire, so passing faire vnkind,
And of such worth and right to be vnkind,
(Since no man can be worthie of her kindnesse.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What can there not?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: No, that is sure as death,
No man aliue: I doe not say is not,
But cannot possibly be worth her kindnesse.
Nay that is certaine, let me doe her Right:
How said I? do her Right? as though I could,
As though this dull grosse tongue of mine could vtter
The rare, the true, the pure, the infinite Rights
That sit (as high as I can looke) within her.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: This is such dotage as was neuer heard.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Well, this must needs be granted.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: Graunted quoth you?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Nay Macilente; doe not so discredit
The goodnesse of your judgement to denie it,
For I doe speake the very least of her.
And I would craue and beg no more of heauen
For all my fortunes here, but to be able
To vtter first in fit tearmes, what she is,
And then the true joies I conceiue in her.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: Is't possible she should deserue so well
As you pretend?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: I, and she knowes so well
Her owne deserts that (when I striue t'enjoy them)
She waies the things I doe, with what she merits:
And (seeing my worth outwai'd so in her graces)
She is so solemne, so precise, so froward,
That no obseruance I can doe to her,
Can make her kind to me: if she find fault,
I mend that fault, and then she saies I faulted
That I did mend it. Now good Friend aduise me
How I may temper this strange Splene in her.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: You are too amorous, too obsequious,
And make her, too assur'd she may commaund you.
When women doubt most of their husbands loues,
They are most louing. Husbands must take heed
They giue no gluts of kindnesse to their wiues,
But vse them like their Horses, whom they feed
Not with a manger-full of meat together,
But halfe a pecke at once, and keepe them so
Still with an appetite to that they giue them.
He that desires to haue a louing wife,
Must bridle all the shew of that desire:
Be kind, not amorous, nor bewraying kindnesse,
As if Loue wrought it, but considerate Dutie:
"Offer no loue-rites, but let wiues still seeke them,
" For when they come vnsought, they seldome like them.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Beleeue me Macilente, this is Gospell.
O that a man were his owne man so much,
To rule himselfe thus; I will striue i' faith
To be more strange and carelesse: yet I hope
I haue now taken such a perfect course,
To make her kind to me, and liue contented,
That I shall find my kindnesse well return'd,
And haue no need to fight with my affections.
She (late) hath found much fault with euery roome
Within my house; One was too big (she said)
Another was not furnisht to her mind,
And so through all: All which I haue alter'd.
Then here she hath a place (on my backeside)
Wherein shee loues to walke; and that (shee said)
Had some ill smels about it. Now this walke
Haue I (before she knowes it) thus perfum'd
With herbes and flowers, and laid in diuerse places
(As 'twere on Altars consecrate to her)
Perfumed Gloues, and delicate chaines of Amber,
To keepe the aire in awe of her sweet nosthrils:
This haue I done, and this I thinke will please her.
Behold she comes.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Here's a sweet stinke indeed:
What, shall I euer be thus crost and plagu'd?
And sicke of Husband? O my head doth ake
As it would cleaue asunder with these sauors,
All my Room's alter'd, and but one poore Walke
That I delighted in, and that is made
So fulsome with perfumes, that I am fear'd
(My braine doth sweat so) I haue caught the Plague.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Why (gentle wife) is now thy Walke too sweet?
Thou said'st of late it had sower aires about it,
And found'st much fault, that I did not correct it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, and I did find fault Sir?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Nay deere wife;
I know thou hast said thou hast lou'd perfumes,
No woman better.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I, long since perhaps,
But now that Sence is alterd: you would haue me
(Like to a puddle or a standing poole)
To haue no motion, nor no spirit within me.
No, I am like a pure and sprightly Riuer,
That moues for euer, and yet still the same;
Or fire that burnes much wood, yet still one flame.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: But yesterday, I saw thee at our garden
Smelling on Roses and on purple flowers,
And since I hope the Humor of thy Sence
Is nothing chang'd.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Why those were growing flowers,
And these within my walke are cut and strew'd.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: But yet they haue one sent.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I, haue they so?
In your grosse judgement: if you make no difference
Betwixt the sent of growing flowers and cut ones,
You haue a sence to tast Lampe-oyle, yfaith.
And with such judgement haue you chang'd the chambers,
Leauing no roome that I can joy to be in
In all your house: and now my Walke and all
You smoke me from, as if I were a Foxe,
And long belike to driue me quite away:
Well walke you there, and I'le walke where I list.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: What shall I doe? oh I shall neuer please her.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Out on thee dotard, what starre rul'd his birth?
That brought him such a Starre? blind Fortune still
Bestowes her gifts on such as cannot vse them:
How long shall I liue, ere I be so happie,
To haue a wife of this exceeding Forme?
Away with 'hem, would I had broke a joint,
When I deuis'd this that should so dislike her,
Away, be are all away.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I doe: for feare.
Ought that is there should like her. O this man
How cunningly he can conceale himselfe,
As though he lou'd? lou'd? nay honour'd and ador'd?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Why, my sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Sweet heart? oh, better still:
And asking, why? wherefore? and looking strangely,
As if he were as white as innocence.
Alas, you'r simple, you: you cannot change,
Looke pale at pleasure, and then red with Wonder:
No, no, not you: I did but cast an amorous eye e'en now
Vpon a paire of Gloues that somwhat likt me,
And straight he noted it, and gaue commaund
All should be ta'ne away.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Be they my bane then:
What sirra, Fido, bring in those Gloues againe
You tooke from hence.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: S'body sirra, but do not:
Bring in no Gloues to spite me: if you doe—

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Ay me, most wretched; how am I misconstru'd?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: O, how she tempts my heart-strings with her eye,
To knit them to her Beauties, or to breake?
What mou'd the heauens, that they could not make
Me such a woman? but a man; a Beast,
That hath no blisse like to others. Would to God
(In wreake of my misfortunes) I were turn'd
To some faire water-Nymph, that set vpon
The deepest whirlepit of the rau'nous Seas,
My Adamantine eyes might headlong hale
This Iron world to me, and drowne it all.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Behold, behold, the translated Gallant.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, he is welcome.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p:
God saue you Brother, and Sister, God saue you sir; I haue commendations for you out i'the countrey: (I wonder they take no knowledge of my Sute:) mine Vncle Soghardo is in towne; Sister, me thinkes you are Melancholly: why are you so sad? I thinke you tooke me for Master Fastidius Briske
(Sister) did you not?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why should I take you for him?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay nothing, I was lately in Maister Fastidius his companie, and me thinkes we are very like.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: You haue a faire suit Brother, God giue you joy on't.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Faith good ynough to ride in Brother, I made it to ride in.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O, now I see the cause of his idle demaund was his new suit.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Pray you good Brother; trie if you can change her mood.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I warrant you, let mee alone. I'le put her out of her dumpes. Sister, how like you my suit?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O you are a gallant in print now Brother.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Faith, how like you the fashion? it's the last Edition I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I cannot but like it to the desert.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Troth sister, I was faine to borrow these Spurres, I ha' left my gowne in gage for 'hem, pray you lend me an angell.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Now beshrow my heart then.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Good truth I'le pay you againe at my next exhibitior: I had but bare tenne pound of my father, and it would not reach to put me wholly into the fashion.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I had Spurres of mine owne before, but they were not Ginglers. Monsieur Fastidius will be here anone Sister.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: You jest?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Neuer lend me penny more (while you liue then) and that I'ld be loth to say, in truth.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: When did you see him?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Yesterday, I came acquainted with him at Sir Puntarvolo's: nay sweet Sister.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I faine would know of heauen now, why yond foole
Should weare a suit of Sattin? he? that Rooke?
That painted Iay with such a deale of outside?
What is his inside trow? ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.
Good Heauen giue me patience,
A number of these Popenjayes there are,
Whom if a man conferre, and but examine
Their inward merit, with such men as want;
Lord, Lord, what things they are!

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Come, when will you pay me againe now?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O God Sister.

div.stage: Enter Fastidius Briske in a new suit.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Here comes another.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Saue you Signior Deliro: how do'st thou sweet Ladie? Let me kisse thee.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: How? a new sute? Ay mee.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: And how do's Maister Fastidius Briske?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith liue in court Signior Deliro, in grace I thanke God, both of the noble Masculine and Feminine. I must speake with you in priuate by and by.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: When you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why looke you so pale brother?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: S'lid all this money is cast away now.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I, ther's a newer Edition come forth.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Tis but my hard fortune: wel, I'le haue my sute chang'd, I'le goe fetch my tailor presently, but first I'le deuise a letter to my father. Ha' you any pen and inke Sister?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: What would you doe withall?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I would vse it. S'light and it had come but foure daies sooner the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: There was a Countesse gaue mee her hand to kisse to day i' the presence: 'did me more good by Iesu, then, and yesternight sent her Coach twise to my lodging, to intreat me accompanie her, and my sweet mistresse, with some two or three namelesse Ladies more: O, I haue been grac't by 'hem beyond all aime of affection: this' her garter my dagger hangs in: and they doe so commend and approue my apparell, with my judicious wearing of it, it's aboue wonder.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, 'tis a most excellent suit, and you do weare it as extraordinarie.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why I'le tell you now (in good faith) and by this Chaire, which (by the grace of God) I entend presently to sit in, I had three Sutes in one yeere, made three great Ladies in loue with me: I had other three, vndid three Gentlemen in imitation: & other three, gat three other Gentlemen, Widdowes of three thousand pound a yeere.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O beleeue it sir; your good Face is the Witch, & your Apparell the Spells, that bring all the pleasures of the world into their Circle.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Ah, the sweet Grace of a Courtier!

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, would my father had left me but a good Face for my portion yet; though I had shar'd the vnfortunate Wit that goes with it, I had not car'd: I might haue past for somewhat i'the world then.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why, assure you Signior, rich apparell has strange vertues: it makes him that hath it without meanes, esteemed for an excellent Wit: he that enjoyes it with means, puts the world in remembrance of his meanes: it helpes the deformities of Nature, and giues Lustre to her beauties; makes continuall Holiday where it shines; sets the wits of Ladies at worke, that otherwise would be idle: furnisheth your two-shilling Ordinarie; takes possession of your Stage at your new Play; and enricheth your Oares, as scorning to go with your Scull.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Pray you sir, adde this; it giues Respect to your fooles, makes many Theeues, as many Strumpets, and no fewer Bankrupts.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Out, out, vnworthy to speake where he breatheth.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: What's he, Signior?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: A friend of mine, sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By heauen, I wonder at you Cittizens, what kind of Creatures you are?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: That you can consort your selues with such poore seame-rent fellowes.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: He sayes true.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Sir I will assure you( how euer you esteeme of him) hee's a man worthie of regard.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why? what ha's he in him of such vertue to bee reguarded? ha?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Marry he is a Scholler Sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: And he is well trauail'd.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: He should get him cloths: I would cherish those good parts of trauell in him, and preferre him to some Nobleman of good place.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Sir, such a benefit should bind me to you for euer (in my friends right) and I doubt not but his desert shall more than answere my praise.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why, and he had good cloths, I'ld carrie him to the Court with me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Hee shall not want for those Sir, if Gold and the whole Cittie will furnish him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: You say well Sir: faith Signior Deliro, I am come to haue you play the Alchymist with me, and chaunge the Species of my land, into that mettall you talke of.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir, what summe will serue you?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith some three or fourescore pound.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Troth Sir I haue promist to meet a Gentleman this morning in Paules, but vpon my returne I'le dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I'le accompanie you thither.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: As you please Sir; but I goe not thither directly.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I haue no other designement in hand, and therefore as good goe along.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p:
I were as good haue a Quartane feauer follow me now, for I shall ne're bee rid of him: (bring me a Cloke there one) Still vpon his grace at the Court am I sure to be visited; I was a beast to giue him any hope. Wel, would I were in that I am out with him once, and— Come Signior Macilente, I must conferre with you as wee goe. Nay deere wife, I beseech thee forsake these moods: looke not like winter thus. Here take my keres, open my counting houses, spread all my wealth before
thee, choose any object that delights thee: If thou wilt eate the spirit of Gold, and drinke dissolu'd Pearle in wine, 'tis for thee.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: So Sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Nay my sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Good Lord! how you are perfumed in your tearmes and all: pray you leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Adiew, sweet Ladie.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I, I, Let thy words euer sound in mine eares, and thy Graces disperse contentment through all my sences: O, how happie is that Ladie aboue other Ladies, that enjoyes so absolute a Gentleman to her Seruant! A Countesse giue him her hand to kisse! ah foolish Countesse; he e's a man worthie (if a woman may speake of a mans worth) to kisse the lips of an Empresse.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: What's Master Fastidius gone, Sister?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I brother: he has a Face like a Cherubin.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Gods me, what lucke's this? I haue fetcht my Taylor and all: which way went he Sister? can you tell?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Not I, in good faith: and hee has a Bodie like an Angell.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: How long is't since he went?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why but e'en now: did you not meet him? and a Tongue able to rauish any woman i'the earth.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: O, for Gods sake (I'le please you for your paines:) but e'en now, say you? Come good sir: S'lid I had forgot it too: Sister, if any body aske for mine Vncle Sogliardo, they shall ha' him at the Heralds Office yonder by Paules.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Well, I will not altogither despaire: I haue heard of a Cittizens wife has been belou'd of a Courtier; and why not I? heigh ho: well, I will into my priuat Chamber, locke the dore to me, and thinke ouer all his good parts one after another.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Well, I doubt this last Scene will endure some grieuous Torture.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How? you feare 'twill be rackt by some hard Construction?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Doe not you?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: No in good faith: vnlesse mine eyes could light mee beyond Sence, I see no reason why this should be more Liable to the Racke than the rest: you'le say perhaps the Cittie will not take it wel, that the Merchant is made here to dote so perfectly vpon his wife; and shee againe, to be so Fastidiously affected, as she is?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: You haue vtter'd my thought sir, indeed.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Why (by that proportion) the Court might as well take offence at him we call the Courtier, and with much more Pretext, by how much the place transcends and goes before in dignitie and vertue: but can you imagine that any Noble or true spirit in the Court (whose Sinewie, and altogither vnaffected graces, very worthily expresse him a Courtier) will make any exception at the opening of such an emptie Trunk as this Briske is? or thinke his owne worth empeacht by beholding his motley inside?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: No Sir, I doe not.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p:
No more, assure you, will any graue wise Cittizen, or modest Matron, take the object of this Follie in Deliro and his Wife; but rather apply it as the foile to their owne vertues: For that were to affirme, that a man writing of Nero, should meane all Emperours: or speaking of Machiavell, comprehend all States-men; or in our Sordido, all Farmars; and so of the rest: than which, nothing can bee vtter'd more malicious and absurd. Indeed there are a sort of these narrow-ey'd Decipherers, I confesse, that will extort straunge and abstruse meanings out of any Subject, bee it neuer so Conspicuous and Innocently deliuerd. But to such( where e're they sit conceald) let them know, the Authour defies them, and their writing-Tables; and hopes, no sound or safe judgement will infect it selfe with their contagious Comments, who
(indeed) come here only to pervert and poyson the sence of what they heare, and for nought else.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Stay, what new Mute is this that walkes so suspiciously?

div.head: SCENA PRIMA.
div.stage: Enter Cavalier Shift, with two Siquisses in his hand.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O, marry this is one, for whose better Illustration; we must desire you to presuppose the Stage, the middle Isle in Paules; and that, the West end of it.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: So Sir: and what followes?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Faith a whole volume of Humor, and worthie the vnclasping

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: As how? what name doe you giue him first?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Hee hath shift of names Sir: some call him Apple Iohn, some Signior Whiffe, marry his maine standing name is Cavalier Shift: the rest are but as cleane shirts to his Natures

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: And what makes he in Paules now?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Troth as you see, for the aduancement of a Siquis or two; wherein he has so varied himselfe, that if any one of 'hem take, he may hul vp and down i'the Humorous world a litle longer:

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: It seemes then, he beares a very changing saile?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O, as the wind Sir: here comes More.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: This is rare, I haue set vp my bils without discouerie.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: What? Signior Whiffe? what fortune has brought you into these West parts?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Troth Signior, nothing but your Rheume; I haue ben taking an ounce of Tabacco hard by here with a gentleman, and I am come to spit priuate in Paules. God saue you Sir.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: A dieu good Signior Whiffe.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Maister Apple Iohn? you are well met: when shall wee sup together, and laugh and be fat with those good wenches? ha?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Faith Sir, I must now leaue you, vpon a few Humours and occasions: but when you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Farewell sweet Apple Iohn: I wonder there are no more store of Gallants here?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What be these two, Signior?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Mary a couple sir, that are meere straungers to the whole scope of our Play; only come to walke a turne or two i'this Scene of Paules by chaunce.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: Saue you, good Master Clouc.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Sweet Master Orenge.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: How? Cloue, and Orenge?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I, & they are well met, for 'tis as dry an Orenge as euer Grew: nothing but Salutation, and O God sir, and It pleases you to say so Sir; one that can laugh at a jest for companie with a most plausible, and extemporall grace; and some houre after in priuate aske you what it was: the other, Monsieur Cloue, is a more spic't youth: he wil sit you a whole afternoon sometimes, in a book-sellers shop, reading the Greeke, Italian, and Spanish; when hee vnderstands not a word of either: if hee had the Tongues to his Sutes, he were an excellent Linguist.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Doe you heare this reported for certeintie?

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: O good sir.

div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Carlo: two seruing men following, one leading the Dogge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sirrah, take my Cloake: and you sir knaue, follow me closer: if thou loosest my Dogge, thou shalt die a Dogges death; I will hang thee.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Tut, feare him not, hee's a good leane slaue, hee loues a Dogge well I warrant him; I see by his lookes, I: masse hee's somewhat like him. Sblood poyson him, make him away with a crooked pinne, or somwhat man; thou maist haue more securitie of thy life: and so Sir, what? you ha' not put out your whole venter yet? ha' you?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
No, I doe want yet some fifteene or sixteene hundred
pounds: but my Ladie (my wife) is out of her Humor; she does not now goe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No? how then?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Mary, I am now enforc't to giue it out, vpon the returne of my selfe, my Dogge, and my Cat.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Your Cat? where is shee?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: My Squire has her there in the Bag: Sirrah, looke to her: How lik'st thou my change, Carlo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Oh, for the better sir; your Cat has nine liues, & your wife ha' but one.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Besides, shee will neuer be Sea-sicke, which will saue me so much in Conserues: when saw you Signior Sogliardo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I came from him but now, hee is at the Heralds Office yonder: hee requested me to goe afore and take vp a man or two for him in Paules, against his Cognisance was readie.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What? has he purchast armes then?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I, and rare ones too: of as many Colours, as e're you saw any fooles coat in your life. I'le go look among yond' Bills, and I can fit him with Legs to his Armes.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: With Legs to his Arms! Good: I will go with you sir.

div.stage: They goe to looke vpon the Bills.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Come, lets walke in the Mediterraneum: I assure you sir I am not the least respected among Ladies; but let that passe: doe you know how to goe into the Presence Sir?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why, on my feet sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No, on your head sir: for 'tis that must beare you out, I assure you: as thus sir: You must first haue an especiall care so to weare your Hat, that it oppresse not confusedly this your Predominant or Fore-top; because (when you come at the Presence dore) you may with once or twice stroking vp your Forehead thus, enter with your Predominant perfect: that is, standing vp stiffe.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: As if one were frighted?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p:
Which indeed, a true feare of your Mistresse should
doe, rather than Gumme water, or whites of Egges: is't not so Sir?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: An Ingenious obseruation: giue mee leaue to craue your name sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: His name is Macilente sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good Signior Macilente: if this Gentleman, Signior Deliro, furnish you (as he saies he will) with clothes, I will bring you to morrow by this time into the Presence of the most Diuine and Acute Ladie of the Court: you shall see sweet Silent Rhetorique, and Dumbe Eloquence speaking in her eye; but when shee speakes her selfe, such an Anatomie of Wit, so Sinewiz'd and Arteriz'd, that 'tis the goodliest Modell of pleasure that euer was, to behold. Oh, shee strikes the world into Admiration of her; (O, O, O) I cannot expresse 'hem beleeue me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O, your onely Admiration, is your silence, sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: 'Fore God Carlo, this is good; let's read 'hem againe: If there be any Ladie, or Gentlewoman of good carriage, that is desirous to entertaine (to her priuat vses) a young, straight, and vpright Gentleman, of the age of fiue, or sixe and twentie at the most: who can serue in the nature of a Gentleman Vsher, and hath little legges of purpose, and a blacke Satten Sute of his owne to goe before her in: which Sute (for the more sweetning) now lyes in Lauander: and can hide his face with her Fanne, if need require: or sit in the cold at the stayre foot for her as well as an other Gentleman: Let her subscribe her Name and Place, and diligent respect shall bee giuen. This is aboue measure excellent: ha?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No this, this: here's a fine slaue.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
If this Cittie, or the Sub-urbs of the same, doe affourd any yong Gentleman, of the first, second, or third head, more or lesse, whose friends are but lately deceased, & whose lands are but new come to his hands, that (to bee as exactly qualified as the best of our Ordinaric Gallants are) is affected to entertaine the most Gentlemanlike vse of Tabacco: as first, to giue it the most exquisite Persume: then, to know all the delicate sweet Formes for the Assumption of it: as also the rare Corollarie and practise of the Cuban Ebolition, EVRIPVS, and Whiffe; which wee
shall receiue or take in here at London, and evaporate at Vxbridge, or farder, if it please him. If there be any such Generous spirit, that is truly enamour'd of these good faculties: May it please him, but (by a note of his hand) to specifie the place, or Ordinarie where he vses to eat and Lie, and most sweete attendance with Tabacco, and Pipes of the best sort shall be ministred: STET QVAESO CANDIDE LECTOR. why this is without Paralell, this!

sp.speaker: Carlo
sp.p: Well, I'le marke this fellow for Sogliardo's vse presently.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Or rather, Sogliardo for his vse.

sp.speaker: Carlo.
sp.p: Faith either of 'hem will serue, they are both good Properties: I'le designe the other a place too, that we may see him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: No better place than the Mitre, that we may be Spectators with you Carlo. Soft, behold, who enters here: Signior Sogliardo! God saue you.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Saue you good sir Punt arvolo; your Dogge's in health sir I see: how now Carlo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: We haue ta'ne simple paines to choose you out followers here.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come hither Signior.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Monsieur Orenge, yond' Gallants obserues vs; pr'y thee let's talke Fustian a little and gull 'hem: make 'hem beleeue we are great Schollers.

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: O Lord sir.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Nay, pr'y thee let's, by Iesu; you haue an excellent habit in discourse.

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: It pleases you to say so sir.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: By this Church you ha' la: nay come, begin: Aristotle in his Daemonologia approoues Scaliger for the best Nauigator in his time: and in his Hypercritiques, hee reports him to be Heautontimoroumenos: you vnderstand the Greeke sir?

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: O God sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: For societies sake hee does. O here be a couple of fine tame Parrats.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Now Sir, Whereas the Ingenuitie of the time, and the soules Synderisis are but Embrions in Nature, added to the panch of Esquiline, and the Inter-vallum of the Zodiack, besides the Eclipticke line being Opticke, and not Mentall, but by the contemplatiue and Theoricke part there of, doth demonstrate to vs the vegetable circumference, and the ventositie of the Tropicks, and whereas our intellectuall or mincing capreall, (according to the Metaphisickes) as you may read in Plato's Histriomastix. You conceiue me Sir?

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: O Lord Sir.

sp.speaker: Cloue.
sp.p: Then comming to the pretie Animall, as Reason long since is fled to Animals you know, or indeed for the more modellizing or enamelling, or rather diamondizing of your subiect, you shall perceiue the Hipothersis or Galaxia, (where of the Meteors long since had their Initiall inceptions and Notions) to be meerely Pithagoricall, Mathematicall, and Aristocraticall: for looke you Sir, there is euer a kind of Concinnitie and Species. Let us turne to our former discourse, for they marke vs not.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Masse, yonder's the knight Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: And my cousin Sogliardo me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I, and his familiar that haunts him, the Deuill with a shining face.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Let 'hem alone, obserue 'hem not.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay I will haue him, I am resolute for that, by this Parchment Gentlemen, I haue ben so toil'd among the Harrots yonder, you will not beleeue, they doe speake i'the straungest language, and giue a man the hardest termes for his money, that euer you knew.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But ha' you armes? ha' your armes?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Yfaith, I thanke God I can write my selfe Gentleman now, here's my Pattent, it cost me thirtie pound by this breath.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: A very faire Coat, well charg'd and full of Armorie.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay, it has as much varietie of colours in it, as you haue seene a Coat haue, how like you the Crest Sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I vnderstand it not well, what is't?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Marry Sir, it is your Bore without a head Rampant.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: A Bore without a head, that's very rare.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, and Rampant too: troth I commend the Heralds wit, he has deciphered him well: A Swine without a head, without braine, wit, any thing indeed, Ramping to Gentilitie. You can blazon the rest signior? can you not?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: OI, I haue it in writing here of purpose, it cost me two shillings the tricking.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Let's heare, Let's heare.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: It is the most vile, foolish, absurd, palpable, and ridiculous Escutcheon that euer this eye survis'd. Saue you good Mounsieur Fastidius.

div.stage: They salute as they meet in the walke.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Silence good knight: on, on.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: GYRONY of eight peeces, AZVRE and GVLES, between three plates a CHEV'RON engrailed checkey, OR, VERT and ERMINES; on a cheefe ARGENT between two ANN'LETS, sables a Bores head PROPER

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How's that? on a cheefe ARGENT?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: On a Cheefe ARGENT, a Bores head PROPER betweene two ANN'LETS sables.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: S'lud, it's a Hogs Cheeke and Puddings in a Peuter field this

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How like you them signior?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Let the word be, Not without mustard, your Crest is very rare sir.

div.stage: Here they Shift, Fast mixes with Punt. Carl. and Sogli. Deliro and Macilente, Cloue and Orenge, foure couple.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: A frying pan to the Crest had had no fellow.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Intreat your poore friend to walke off a little Signior, I will salute the knight.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come, lap't vp, lap't vp.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: You are right wel encountred sir, how do's your fair Dog?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: In reasonable state sir, what Cittizen is that you were consorted with? a merchant of any worth?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis Signior Deliro sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Is it he? Saue you sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Good sir Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O what Copie of foole would this place minister to one endew'd with Patience to obserue it?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay looke you sir, now you are a Gentleman, you must carry a more exalted presence, change your mood and habite to a more austere forme, be exceeding proud, stand vpon your Gentilitie, and scorne euery man. Speak nothing humbly, neuer discourse vnder a Nobleman, though you ne're saw him but riding to the Starre-chamber, it's all one. Loue no man, Trust no man, Speake ill of no man to his face, nor well of any man behind his backe. Salute fairly on the front, and wish 'hem hangd vpon the turne. Spread your selfe vpon his bosome publickely, whose heart you would eat in priuat. These be principles, think on 'hem, I'le come to you againe presently.

div.stage: Exit Car. Sogliardo mixes with Punt. and Fast.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Sirah, keep close, yet not so close, thy breath wil thaw my ruffe.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O good cousin, I am a little busie, how do's my neece, I am to walk with a knight here.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O he is here, look you sir, that's the Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: What he i'the blush-colour'd Sattin?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: I, he sir, though his Sute blush, he blushes not: look you, that's the Sute sir: I would haue mine, such a Sute without difference, such Stuffe, such a Wing, such a Sleeue, such a Skirt, Belly & all; therfore, pray you obserue it. Haue you a pair of Tables?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why do you see sir? they say I am Phantastical: why true, I know it, & I pursue my Humor stil in contempt of this censorious age: S'light & a man should do nothing but what a sort of stale iudgements about this town wil approue in him, he were a sweet Asse, Il'd beg him yfaith: I ne're knew any more find fault with a fashion, then they that knew not how to put themselues into't. For mine owne part, so I please mine own appetite, I am carelesse what the fustie World speakes of me, puh:

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Doe you marke how it hangs at the knee there?

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: For Gods sake do, note all: do you see the Coller sir?

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: Feare nothing, it shall not differ in a stitch sir.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Pray God it do not, you'le make these linings serue? & helpe me to a Chapman for the outside, will you?

sp.speaker: Tail.
sp.p: I'le doe my best sir: you'le put it off presently:

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I, goe with me to my chamber you shall haue it, but make hast of it, for the loue of Christ, for I'le sit i' my old sute, or else lie a bed and read the Arcadia, till you haue done.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, if euer you were strucke with a jest, gallants, now, now. I doe vsher the most strange peece of Militarie Profession, that euer was discouer'd in Insula Paulina.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What is he for a Creature?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A Pimpe, a Pimpe, that I haue obseru'd yonder, the rarest Superficies of a Humor; hee comes euery morning to emptie his lungs in Paules here, and offers vp some fiue or six Hecatomb's of faces and sighes, and away againe. Here he comes; nay walk, walke, be not seene to note him, and wee shall haue excellent sport.

div.stage: Walkes by, and vses action to his-Rapier.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: S'lid he vented a sigh e'ne now, I thought hee would haue blowne vp the church.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O you shall haue him giue a number of those false fires ere he depart.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: See now he is expostulating with his Rapier, Looke, Looke.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Did you euer in your daies obserue better passion ouer a hilt?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Except it were in the person of a Cutlers boy, or that the fellow were nothing but Vapour, I should thinke it impossible.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: See, again, he claps his sword o'the head, as who should say, Well, goe to.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O violence, I wonder the blade can containe it selfe, being so prouokt.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: With that, the moodie Squire thumpt his brest,
And rear'd his eyen to Heauen for Reuenge.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Troth, and you be Gentlemen, Let's make 'hem friends, and take vp the matter betweene his Rapier and he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Nay, if you intend that, you must lay downe the matter,
for this Rapier (it seemes) is in the nature of a Hanger on, and the good Gentleman would happily be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By my faith, and 'tis to be suspected, I'le aske him.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: O here 's rich stuffe, for Christ sake, let vs goe,
A man would wish himselfe a sencelesse pillar,
Rather than view these monstrous prodigies:
Nil habet infelix Paupertas durius in se,
Quam quod Ridiculos homines facit.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: At your seruice.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Will you sell your Rapier?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Sbloud he is turn'd wild vpon the question, hee lookes as he had seene a Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sell my Rapier? now God blesse me.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: You ask't me, if I would sell my Rapier Sir?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I did indeed.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Now Lord haue mercie vpon me.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Amen I say still.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: S'lud Sir, what should you behold in my face Sir, that should moue you (as they say Sir) to aske me Sir, if I would sell my Rapier?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Nay (let me pray you Sir) bee not mou'd: I protest I would rather haue been silent than any way offensiue, had I knowne your nature.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p:
Sell my Rapier? Gods lid: Nay Sir (for mine own part) as I am a man that has seru'd in causes, or so, so I am not apt to injure any Gentleman in the degree of falling foule, but: sell my Rapier? I will tell you Sir, I haue seru'd with this foolish Rapier, where some of vs dare not appeare in hast, I name no man: but let that passe; Sell my Rapier? Death to my Lungs. This Rapier Sir, has trauail'd by my side Sir, the best part of Fraunce and the low Countrey: I haue seene Vlishing, Brill, and the Haghe with this Rapier sir, in my Lord of Leysters time: and (by Gods will) he that should offer to disrapier me now, I would.— Looke you sir, you presume to bee a Gentleman of good sort,
and so likewise your friends here, if you haue any disposition to trauell, for the sight of seruice or so, One, two, or all of you, I can lend you letters to diuers Officers and Commaunders in the Low Countries, that shall for my cause do you all the good offices that shall pertaine or belong to Gentlemen of your— Please you to shew the Bountie of your mind Sir, to impart some ten groates or halfe a Crowne to our vse, till our abilitie be of grow'th to returne it, and we shall thinke our selfe.— Sbloud, sell my Rapier?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I pray you what said he Signior, hee's a proper man.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Mary hee tells me, If I please to shew the bountie of my mind, to impart some ten groats to his vse or so.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Breake his head, and giue it him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I thought he had been playing on the Iewes Trump I.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: My Rapier? no Sir: my Rapier is my Guard, my Defence, my Reuenew, my Honour: (if you cannot impart bee secret I beseech you) and I will maintaine it, where there is a graine of dust or a drop of water: (hard is the choise when the valiant must eat their Armes or clem:) Sell my Rapier? no my Deare, I will not be diuorc't from thee yet, I haue euer found thee true as Steele: and (you cannot impart Sir) God saue you Gentlemen: (neuerthelesse if you hauie a fancie to it sir.)

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Pr'y thee away: is Signior Deliro departed?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ha' you seene a Pimpe out-face his owne wants better.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I commend him, that can dissemble them so well.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: True, and hauing no better a cloake for it than he has neither.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Gods precious, what mischieuous lucke is this: adiew Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Whither Monsieur such hast, Monsieur Fastidius?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: After my Merchant, Signior Deliro sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O hinder him not, he may hap loose his Tide, a good Flounder i' faith.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: Harke you Sig. Whiffe, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? Signior Whiffe?

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: What was the difference betweene thast young Gallant that's gone, and you sir.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p:
No difference: hee would ha' giu'n me fiue pound for
my Rapier, and I refus'd it; that's all.

sp.speaker: Clou.
sp.p: O, was it no otherwise? we thought you had ben vpon some terms.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: No other than you saw sir.

sp.speaker: Clou.
sp.p: Adieu good Master Apple Iohn.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? Whiffe, and Apple Ioan too? Hart, what'll you say if this be the Appendix, or Labell to both yond' Indentures?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: It may be.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Resolue vs of it Ianus, thou that lookst euery way; or thou Hercules, that hast trauail'd all Countries.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Nay Carlo, spend not time in Inuocations now; tis late.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Signior, here's a Gentleman desirous of your name sir.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sir, my name is Caualier Shift: I am knowne sufficiently in this walke sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Shift? I heard your name varied e'en now, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: True sir, it pleases the world (as I am her excellent Tabacconist) to giue me the Style of Signior Whiffe: as I am a poore Esquire about the towne here, they call me Master Apple Iohn: varietie of good names does well sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, and good parts, to make those good names: out of which I imagine yond' Bills to be yours.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sir, if I should denie the Scriptures, I were worthy to be banisht the middle I'le for euer.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I take your word Sir: this Gentleman has subscrib'd to 'hem, & is most desirous to become your Pupil; mary you must vse expedition: Signior Insulso Sogliardo, this is the Professor.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: In good time sir, nay good sir house your head, doe your professe these sleights in Tabacco?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I doe more than professe sir, and (if you please to be a practioner) I wil vndertake in one fortnight to bring you, that you shall take it plausibly in any Ordinarie, Theatre, or the Tilt-yard if need be; the most popular assembly that is.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: But you cannot bring him to the Whiffe so soone?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Yes as soone sir; he shall receiue the 1, 2, and 3 Whiffe, if it please him, & (vpon the receit) take his horse, drinke his three cups of Canarie, and expose one at Hounslow, a second at Stanes, and a third at Bagshot.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Baw-waw.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: You wil not serue me sir, will youn? I'le giue you more than Countenance.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I doe scorne to serue any man.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Who? he serue? Sbloud he keeps High men, & Low men, he; he has a faire liuing at Fullam.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: But in the nature of a fellow, I'le bee your follower if you please.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Sir you shall stay and dine with me, and if we can agree, weele not part in hast: I am very bountifull to men of qualitie. Where shall we go Signior.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Your Miter is your best house.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I can make this dog take as many whiffes as I list, and he shall retaine or efume them at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: By your patience, follow me fellowes.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Sir Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Pardon me, my Dog shall not eat in his companie for a Million.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay be not you amaz'd signior Whiffe, what e're that stiffeneckt Gentleman say's.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: No, for you doe not know the Humor of the dog as wee do: where shall we dine Carlo? I would faine goe to one of these Ordinaries now I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: So you may, were you neuer at none yet?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: No faith, but they say there resorts your most choise gallants.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: True, and the fashion is, when any straunger comes in amongst 'hem, they all stand vp and stare at him, as hee were some vnknowne beast brought out of Affricke, but that'll bee help't with a good adventurous face, you must bee impudent ynough, sit downe and vse no respect, when any thing's propounded aboue your capacitie, smile at it, make two or three faces, and 'tis excellent, they'le thinke you haue trauail'd: though you argue a whole day in Silence thus, and discourse in nothing but Laughter, 'twill passe. Onely (now and then) giue fire, Discharge a good full Oth, and offer a great Wager, 'twill be admirable.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I warrant you, I am resolute, come good Signior, theres a poore French crowne for your Ordenarie.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: It comes well, for I had not so much as the least Portcullice of come before.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I trauell with another objection Signior, which I feare will be enforc'd against the Author, ere I can be deliuer'd of it

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: What's that sir?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: That the argument of his Comedie might haue ben of some other nature, as of a Duke to be in loue with a Countesse, & that Countesse to be in loue with the Dukes son, & the son to loue the Ladies waiting maid: some such crosse woing, with a Clowne to their seruingman, better than to be thus neere and familiarly allied to the time.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: You say well, but I would faine hear one of these Autumne- judgements define once, Quid sit Comoedia? if he cannot, let him content himselfe with Ciceros definition (till hee haue strength to propose to himself a better) who would haue a Comedie to be Imitatio vitae, Speculum Consuetudinis, Imago veritatis, a thing throughout pleasant and ridiculous, and accommodated to the correction of manners: if the maker haue fail'd in any particle of this, they may worthily taxe him, but if not, why; be you (that are for them) silent, as I will bee for him; and giue way to the Actors.

div.head: SCENA SECUNDA
div.stage: Enter Sordido with a halter about his necke.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: Nay Gods-pretious, if the weather and the Season be so respectlesse, that Beggers shall liue as well as their betters; and that my hunger and thirst for Riches, shall not make them hunger and thirst with Pouertie; that my sleepes shall be broken, and their hearts not broken; that my coffers shall be full, and yet care; theirs emptie, and yet merry: Tis time that a Crosse should beare flesh and bloud, since flesh and bloud cannot beare this crosse.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What will he hang himselfe?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Faith I, it seemes his Prognostication has not kept touch with him, and that makes him despaire.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Be shrow me, he wil be out of his Humor then indeed.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: Tut, these star-monger knaues, who would trust 'hem? one saies, darke and rainie, when 'tis as cleare as Christall; another saies, tempestuous blasts, and stormes, and 'twas as calme as a Milke bowle; here be sweet rascals for a man to credite his whole fortunes with: You skie-staring Cocks combes you: you fat braines, out upon you; you are good for nothing but to sweat night-caps and make rug-gownes deare: you learned men, and haue not a Legion of Deuils, a vostre seruice: a vostre seruice? By heauen I thinke I shall die a better scholler than they, but soft, how now sirah.

div.stage: Enter a Hind with a letter.

sp.speaker: Hind.
sp.p: Here's a letter come from your Sonne sir.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: From my Sonne sir? what would my Sonne sir? some good newes no doubt.

floatingText.head: The letter.
floatingText.p: Sweet and deare father, (desiring you first to send mee your blessing, which is more worth to me than Gold or Siluer) I desire you likewise to bee aduertised, that this Shrouctide (contrarie to custome) wee vse alwaies to haue Reuels; which is indeed Dauncing, and makes an excellent shew in truth; especially if wee Gentlemen bee well attir'd, which our Seniors note, and thinke the better of our fathers, the better wee are maintain'd, and that they shall know if they come vp, and haue any thing to doe in the Law: therefore good Father, these are (for your owne sake as well as mine) to re-desire you, that you let me not want that which is fit for the setting vp of our name in the honourable volume of Gentilitie, that I may say to our Calumnators with Tullie, EGO SVM ORTVS DOMVS MEAE, TV OCCASVSTVAE. And thus (not doubting of your fatherly Beneuolence) humbly ask you blessing, and pray God to blesse you.

sp.p:
How's this; Yours, if his owne? is he not my Sonne, except he be his owne Sonne. Belike this is some new kind of subscription the Gallants vse. Well, wherefore doest thou stay knaue?
Away: goe.

div.p: Here's a letter indeed; Reuels? and benevolence? is this a weather to send beneuolence? or is this a season to reuell in? Slid the Deuill and all takes part to vexe me I thinke: this letter would neuer haue come now else, now, now, when the sunne shines, and the aire thus cleare. Soule if this hold, we shall shortly haue an excellent crop of Corne spring out of the high waies, the Streets, and Houses of the towne will be hid with the rankenesse of the fruits that grow there in spight of good Husbandrie. Goe to I'le preuent the sight of it, come as quickly as it can, I will preuent the sight of it. I haue this remedie Heauen: stay; I'le trie the paine thus a little, O, nothing, nothing. Well now: shall my sonne gaine a beneuolence by my death? or any bodie be the better for my Gold or so forth: No Aliue, I kept it from 'hem, and (dead) my ghost shall walke about it and preserue it, my Sonne and Daughter shal sterue ere they touch it, I haue hid it as deepe as Hell from the sight of Heauen, and to it I go now.
div.stage: Enter Rustici, 5 or 6, one after another.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Aye me, what pitifull sight is this? helpe, helpe, help!

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: How now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: O here's a man has hang'd himselfe, helpe to get him againe.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Hang'd himselfe? Slid carry him afore a Iustice, 'tis chance medley on my word.

sp.speaker: Rust. 3
sp.p: How now, what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Rust. 4
sp.p: How comes this?

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: One has executed himselfe contrarie to the order of Law, and by my consent he shall answer't.

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Would he were in case to answere it.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Stand by, he recouers, giue him breath.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Masse, 'twas well you went the footway neighbour.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: I, and I had not cut the halter.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: How? cut the halter? Aye me, I am vndone, I am vndone.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Marry if you had not been vndone, you had beene hang'd I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: You thredbare horse-bread eating rascals, if you would needs haue been medling, could you not haue vntied it, but you must cut it? and in the midst too? Aye me.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Out on me, 'tis the Caterpiller Sordido; how cursed are the poore, that the viper was blest with this good fortune?

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Nay how accurst are thou, that art cause to the curse of the poore?

sp.speaker: Rust. 3
sp.p: I, and to saue so wretched a Caytife.

sp.speaker: Rust. 4
sp.p: Curst be thy fingers that loos'd him.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Some desperate furie possesse thee, that thou maist hang thy selfe too.

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Neuer maiest thou be sau'd, that sau'd so damn'd a monster.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.l: What curses breath these men? how haue my deeds
Made my lookes differ from another mans,
That they should thus detest, and loth my life?
Out on my wretched Humor, it is that
Makes me thus monstrous in true humane eies.
Pardon me (gentle friends) I'le make faire mends
For my foule errors past and twentie-fold
Restore to all men, what with wrong I rob'd them:
My Barnes and Garners shall stand open still
To all the poore that come, and my best graine
Be made almes-bread to feed halfe-famisht mouths.
Though hetherto amongst you I haue liu'd
Like an vnsauorie Muck hill to my selfe,
Yet now my gather'd heapes being spread abroad,
Shall turne to better, and more fruitfull vses.
Blesse then this man, curse him no more for sauing
My life and soule together. O how deepely
The bitter curses or the poore do pierce!
I am by wonder chang'd; come in with me
And witnesse my repentance: now I proue,
"No life is blest, that is not grac't with Loue.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: O miracle! see when a man ha's grace.

sp.speaker: Rust. 3
sp.p: Had't not been pitie so good a man should haue ben cast away?

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Well, I'le get our Clarke put his conversion in the Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Rust. 4
sp.p: Doe, for I warrant him hee's a vertuous man.

sp.speaker: Rust.
sp.p: O god how he wept if you mark't it: did you see how the teares trill'd?

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Yes beleeue mee; like maister Vicars bowles vpon the greene, for all the world.

sp.speaker: 3 or 4
sp.p: O neighbour, god's blessing your heart neighbour, 'twas a good gratefull deed.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How now Mitis? what's that you consider so seriously?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Troth, that which doth essentially please me: the warping condition of this greene and soggie multitude: but in good faith Signior, your Author hath largely outstript my expectation in this Scene, I will liberally confesse it. For when I saw Sordido so desperately intended, I thought I had had a hand of him then.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: What? you suppos'd hee should haue hung himselfe indeed?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I did; and had fram'd my objection to it readie, which may yet be very fitly vrg'd, & with some necessitie: for though his purpos'd violence lost th'effect, & extended not to death, yet the Intent & Horror of the object was more than the nature of a Comedie will in any sort allow.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: I? what thinke you of Plautus in his Come die called Cistellaria there? where he brings in Alcesimarchus with a drawne sword readie to kill himselfe, and as hee is e'ne fixing his breast vpon it, to bee restrain'd from his resolu'd outrage by Silenium and the Bawd: is not his authoritie of power to giue our Scene approbation?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p:
Sir, I haue this (your only) euasion left mee, to say, I thinke it bee so indeed, your memorie is happier than mine: but I wonder
what engine he will vse to bring the rest out of their Humors?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: That will appeare anone, neuer preoccupie your imagination withall. Let your mind keepe companie with the Scene stil, which now remoues it selfe from the Countrie to the Court. Here comes Macilente and Signior Briske freshly suted, loose not your selfe, for now the Epitasis or busie part of our Subject is in Action.

div.head: SCENA TERTIA.
div.stage: Enter Macilente, Briske, Cinedo, with Tabacco.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Well now Signior Macilente, you are not onely welcome to the Court, but also to my mistresse with drawing chamber: Boy get me some Tabacco, I'le but goe in, and shew I am here, and come to you presently sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What's that he said? by heauen I markt him not,
My thoughts, and I were of another world;
I was admiring mine owne outside here,
To thinke what priuiledge and palme it beares
Here in the court: Be a man ne're so vile
In wit, in judgement, manners, or what else;
If he can purchase but a Silken couer,
He shall not only passe, but passe regarded:
Whereas let him be poore and meanely clad,
Though ne're so richly parted; you shall haue
A fellow (that knowes nothing but his Beefe
Or how to rince his clammie guts in beere)
Will take him by the shoulders or the throte,
And kicke him downe the staires, Such is the state
Of vertue in bad Cloths, ha, ha, ha, ha,
That Raiment should be in such high request?
How long should I be ere I should put off
To my Lord Chancelors tombe, or the Shriues posts?
By heauen (I think) a thousand thousand yeare,
His Grauities, his wisdome, and his faith,
To my dread Soueraigne (graces that suruiue him)
These I could well endure to reuerence,
But not his Tombe, no more than I'le commend
The Chappell Organ for the guilt without,
Or this bace Violl for the varnisht face.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: In faith I haue made you stay somewhat long sir, but is my Tabacco readie boy?

sp.speaker: Cinc.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Giue me, my mistresse is upon comming, you shall see her presently sir, (Tab.) you'le say you neuer accosted a more piercing wit. This Tabacco is not dried Boy, or else the Pipe's defectiue. Oh, your wits of Italie are nothing comparable to her, her braine's a very Quiuer of jests, and she do's dart them abroad with that sweet loose and judiciall aime that you would— here she comes sir.

div.stage: Enter Sauiolina, and goes in againe.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: 'Twas time, his inuention had been bogd else.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Giue me my fanne there.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: How now Mounsieur Briske?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: A kind of affectionate reuerence strikes me with a cold shiuering( me thinkes.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I like such tempers well, as stand before their Mistresses with feare and trembling, and before their Maker like impudent mountaines.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By Iesu, I'ld spend twentie pound my vauting Horse stood here now, she might see me doe but one tricke?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why do's she loue actiuitie?

sp.speaker: Cine.
sp.p: Or if you had but your long stockings on to be dauncing a Galliard, as she comes by.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I either. O these stirring humors make Ladies mad with desire, she comes. My good Genius embolden me, Boy the Pipe quickly.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What? will he giue her musicke?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: A second good morrow to my faire mistresse.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Faire seruant, I'le thanke you a day hence, when the date of your salutation comes forth.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: How like you that answere? is't not admirable?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I were a simple Courtier, if I could not admire trifles sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Troth sweet Ladie I shall (Tab.) be prepar'd to giue you thankes for those thanks, and (Tab.) studie more officious and obsequous regards (Tab.) to your faire beauties: (Tab.) mend the pipe boy.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I ne're knew Tabacco taken as a parenthesis before.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Fore God (sweet Ladie) beleeue it, I doe honour the meanest rush in this chamber for your loue.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: I, you need not tell me that sir, I do think you do prize a rush before my loue.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Is this the wonder of nations?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O, by Iesu pardon me, I said for your loue, by this light; but it is the accustomed sharpenesse of your Ingenuitie sweet Mistresse to— Masse your Violl's new strung me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: ingenuitie; I see his ignorance will not suffer him to slander her; which he had done most notably, if he had said Wit for Ingenuitie, as he meant it.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By the soule of Musicke Ladie (hum, hum.)

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Would we might heare it once.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I doe more adore and admire your (hum, hum) predominant perfections than (hum, hum) euer I shall haue power and facultie to expresse (hum.)

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Vpon the Violl de Gambo you meane?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: It's miserably out of tune, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Nay rather by the fingers.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: It makes good Harmonie with her wit.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Sweet Ladie tune it. Boy some Tabacco.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Tabacco againe? hee do's court his mistresse with very exceeding good changes.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Signior Macilente, you take none sir? (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: No, vnlesse I had a mistresse Signior, it were a great Indecorum for me to take Tabacco.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: How like you her wit? (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Her ingenuitie is excellent sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
You see the subject of her sweet fingers there? (Tab.) Oh shee tickles it so, that (Tab.) shee makes it laugh most
Diuinely; (Tab.) I'le tell you a good jeast now, and your selfe shall say it's a good one: I haue wisht my selfe to be that Instrument (I thinke) a thousand times, and not so few, by Heauens (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Not vnlike Sir: but how? to be cas'd vp and hung by on the wall?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O, no Sir, to be in vse I assure you; as your judicious eyes may testifie. (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Here Seruant, if you will play, come.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Instantly sweet Ladie (Tab.) In good faith here's most Diuine Tabacco.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot stay to Daunce after your Pipe.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good, nay deare Ladie stay: by this sweet Smoake, I thinke your wit be all fire: (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: And hee's the Salamander that liues by it.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Is your Tabacco perfum'd Sir? that you sweare by the sweet Smoake?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Still more excellent: (before God, and these bright Heauens) I thinke (Tab.) you are made of Ingenuitie, I (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: True, as your discourse is: O abhominable!

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Will your Ladiship take any?

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: O, peace I pray you; I loue not the breath of a Woodcocks head.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Meaning my head, Ladie?

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Not altogither so Sir; but (as it were Fatall to their follies that thinke to grace themselues with taking Tabacco, when they want better entertainment) you see your Pipe beares the true forme of a Woodcocks head.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O Admirable Simile!

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: 'Tis best leauing of you in Admiration, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Are these the admired Ladie-wits, that hauing so good a Plaine-song, can runne no better Diuision vpon it. S'heart, all her jests are of the stampe March was fifteene yeeres agoe. Is this the Comet Monsieur Fastidius, that your Gallants wonder at so?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Hart of a Gentleman to neglect mee afore presence thus: Sweet sir, I beseech you be silent in my disgrace, By Iesu, I neuer was in so vile a Humor in my life, and her wit was at the floud too, Report it not for a million good sir; let me be so farre endear'd to your loue.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What followes next Signior Cordatus? this Gallants Humor is almost spent mee thinkes, it ebbes apace, with this contrarie breath of his mistresse.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O, but it will flow againe for all this, till there come a generall drought of Humor among all our Actors, and then I feare not but his will fall as low as any. See who presents himselfe here:

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What, i'the old case?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Yfaith, which makes it the more pittifull, you vnderstand where the Scene is?

div.head: SCENA PRIMA.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why are you so melancholy Brother?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: I am not melancholy I thanke you Sister.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why are you not merry then? there are but two of vs in all the world, and if we should not be comforts to one another, God helpe vs.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot tell Sister, but if a man had any true Melancholie in him, it would make him melancholie, to see his yeomanly father cut his neighbours throats to make his sonne a Gentleman: and yet when he has cut 'hem, hee will see his sonnes throat cut too, ere he make him a true Gentleman indeed, before Death cut his owne throat I must be the first Head of our house, and yet he will not giue mee the head, till I be made so. Is any man tearm'd a Gentleman that is not alwaies i'the fashion? I would know but that.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p:
If you be melancholy for that Brother, I think I haue
as much cause to be melancholy, as one; for I'le be sworne I liue as little in the fashion, as any woman in London. By the Bible of heauen (beast that I am to say it) I haue not one friend i'the world besides my husband. When saw you Maister Fastidius Briske, Brother?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: But a while since Sister, I thinke, I know not well in truth. By Gods lid I could sight with all my heart me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Nay good Brother, be not resolute.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I sent him a letter, and hee writes mee no answere neither.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Oh sweet Fastidius Briske, O fine Courtier, thou art hee mak'st me sigh and say, How blessed is that woman that hath a Courtier to her husband? and how miserable a dame she is that hath neither husband nor friend in the Court: O sweet Fastidius, O fine Courtier. How comely hee bowes him in his courtesie? how full hee hits a woman betwixt the lips when hee kisses? how vpright hee sits at the Table? how daintily hee carues? how sweetly hee talkes, and tels newes of this Lord, and of that Ladie? how cleanely hee wipes his spoon at euery spoonfull of any whit-meat hee eats, and what a near case of picketooths hee carries about him still? Oh sweet Fastidius, O fine Courtier!

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: See yonder shee is Gentlemen, now (as euer you'le beare the name of Musitians) touch your instruments sweetly, shee has a delicate eare, I tell you, play not a false note I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Feare not Signior Deliro.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O begin, begin, some sprightly thing; Lord, how my imagination labours with the successe of it: well said, good yfaith, heauen graunt it please her, I'le not bee seene, for then shee'le be sure to dislike it.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Hey da, this is excellent, I'le lay my life this is my husbands dotage, I thought so, nay neuer play peeke-boe with me, I know you do nothing but studie how to anger me sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Anger thee, sweet wife? why didst thou not send for Musitians to supper last night thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: To Supper sir? now come vp to Supper I beseech you: as though there were no difference betweene Supper time when folkes should be merrie, and this time when they would be Melancholly? I would neuer take vpon me to take a wife, if I had no more Iudgement to please her.

sp.speaker: Deli
sp.p: Be pleas'd sweet wife, and they shall ha' done: & would to Christ my life were done, if I can neuer please thee.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: God saue you Ladie; where is Master Deliro?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Here, Master Macilente: you'r welcome from the Court Sir; no doubt you haue been grac't exceedingly of Master Briskes Mistresse, and the rest of the Ladies for his sake?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: Alas, the poore Phantasticke, hee's scarse knowne
To any Ladie there: and those that know him,
Know him the simplest man of all they know:
Deride, and play vpon his amorous Humors,
Though he but Apishly doth imitate
The gallan't Courtiers, kissing ladies Pumps,
Holding the Cloth for them, praising their Wits,
And seruilely obseruing euery one,
May doe them pleasure: Fearefull to be seene
With any man (though he be ne're so worthy)
That's not in grace with some that are the greatest.
Thus Courtiers doe, and these he counterfeits,
But sets not such a sightly carriage
Vpon their vanities, as they themselues;
And therefore they despise him: for indeed
Hee's like a Zani to a Tumbler,
That tries trickes after him to make men laugh.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Here's an vnthankfull spitefull wretch: the good Gentleman vouchsaft to make him his companion (because my husband put him into a few Rags) and now see how the vnrude Rascall backbites him.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Is he no more grac't amongst'hem then? say you?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith like a pawne at Chesse, fills vp a roume, that's all.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O monster of men! can the Earth beare such an enuious Caitiffe?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Well, I repent mee I e're credited him so much: but (now I see what he is, and that his masking viz or is of) I'le forbear him no longer: all his lands are morgag'd to me, and forfeited: besides, I haue Bonds of his in my hand for the receit of now xx pound, now xxx, now xxv: still as hee has had a Fan but wagg'd at him, he would be in a new Sute. Wel, I'le salute him by a Sergeant, the next time I see him yfaith, I'le Suit him.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why, you may soone see him Sir, for hee is to meet Signior Puntarvolo at a Notaries by the Exchange presently, where he meanes to take vp vpon returne.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Now out vpon thee Iudas; canst thou not be content to backbite thy friend, but thou must betray him? wilt thou seeke the vndoing of any man? and of such a man too? and will you Sir get your liuing by the counsell of Traitors?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Deare wife, haue patience.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: The house wil fal, the ground wil open, and swallow vs: I'le not bide here for all the Gold an Siluer in Heauen.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O good Macilente, let's follow and appease her, or the Peace of my life is at an end.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Now Pease, and not Peace feed that life, whose head hangs so heauily ouer a womans Manger.

div.stage: Enter Fallace running, at another dore, and claps it too.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Help me brother: Gods body and you come here, I'le do my selfe a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Nay, heare me sweet wife, vnlesse thou wilt haue mee goe, I will not goe.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p:
Tut, you shall ne're ha' that vantage of me, to say you are vndone by mee: I'le not bid you stay, I. Brother, sweet brother, here's foure Angels, I'le giue you toward your Sute; for the loue of Iesu, and as euer you came of Christen creature, make hast to the water side (you know where Master Fastidius vses to land) and giue him warning of my husbands intent; and tell him of that leane Rascals treacherie: O Iesu,
how my flesh rises at him? nay, sweet brother make hast; you may say I would haue writ to him, but that the necessitie of the time would not suffer it: He cannot choose but take it extraordinarily from me: and Commend me to him, good brother: say I sent you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Let me see; these foure Angels: and then fortie shillings more I can borrow on my Gowne in Fetter-lane: well, I will goe presently, say on my Sute, pay as much money as I haue, and sweare my selfe into Credit with my Taylor for the rest.

div.head: SCENA SECUNDA.
div.stage: Enter Deliro, with Macilente, speaking as they passe ouer the Stage.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O, on my Soule you wrong her, Macilente, Though she be froward, yet I know she is honest.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, then haue I no Iudgement; would nay woman (but one that were wild in her affections) haue broke out into that immodest and violent Passion against her husband? or is't possible—

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: If you loue me, forbeare; all the Arguments i'the world shall neuer wrest my heart to beleeue it.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How like you the Deciphering of his Dotage?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, strangely; and of the others Enuie too, that labors so seriously to set debate betwixt a man and his wife, Stay, here comes the Knight Aduenturer.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: I, and his Scriuener with him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I wonder Monsieur Fastidius comes not! but Notarie, if thou please to draw the Indentures the while, I will giue thee the Theorie.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: With all my heart Sir; and I'le fall in hand with 'hem presently.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Well then, first; the Summe is to be vnderstood.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Next, our seuerall Appellations, and Character of my Dog and Cat must be knowne: shew him the Cat Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Then, that the intended Point, is the Turkes Court in Constantinople: the Time limited for our Returne, a yeere: and that if either of vs miscarrie, the whole Venter is lost. These are Generall; conceiu'st thou? or if either of vs turne Turque.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Now for Particulars: that I may make my trauails by Sea or Land, to my best liking: and that (hiring a Coach for my selfe) it shall be lawfull for my Dog and Cat to ride with mee in the said Coach.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That I may choose to giue my Dog or Cat Fish, for feare of Bones, or any other Nutriment, that (by the judgement of the most Autenticall Physicians where I trauaile) shall be thought dangerous.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That (after the receit of his money) he shall neither in his owne person, nor any other, either by direct or indirect meanes; as Magique, Witchcraft, or other such Exoticke Artes, attempt, practise, or complot any thing, to the prejudice of Mee, my Dogge, or my Cat: Neither shall I vse the helpe of any such Sorceries or Enchantments; as Vnctions, to make our skinnes impenetrable, or to trauaile inuisible by vertue of a Pouder, or a Ring, or to hang any three-forked Charme about my Dogs necke, secretly conuey'd into his Collar: vnderstand you? but that all be performed, sincerely, without fraud or Imposture.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That (for testimonie of the Performance) my selfe am to bring thence a Turkes Mustachio, my Dogge a Hares lip, and my Cat the traine or taile of a Rat.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: 'Tis said Sir, not done sir, but forward. That vpon my returne and landing on the Tower wharfe with the aforesaid Testimonie, I am to receiue fiue for one, according to the proportion of the summes putforth.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Prouided, That if before our departure or setting forth, either my selfe, or these be visited with sicknesse, or any other casuall euent, so that the whole course of the Aduenture be hindred thereby; that then, He is to returne, and I am to receiue the prenominated Proportion, vpon faire and equall tearmes.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: Very good sir; is this all?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: It is all Sir: and dispatch them good Notarie.

sp.speaker: Not.
sp.p: As fast as is possible Sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O Carlo, welcome: saw you Monsieur Briske?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not I: did he appoint you to meet here?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I, and I muse he should be so tardie: hee is to take an hundred pounds of mee in venter, if hee maintaine his promise.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is his houre past?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Not yet, but it comes on apace.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Tut, be not jealous of him; he will sooner breake all the ten Commaundements, than his Houre; vpon my life in such a case trust him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Me thinkes Carlo, you looke very smooth? ha?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why I come but now from a Hothouse, I must needs looke smooth.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: From a Hothouse?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I, doe you make a wonder on't? why it's your onely Phisicke. Let a man sweat once a weeke in a Hothouse, and be well rubd and froted with a good plumpe juicie wench, and sweet linnen, he shall ne're ha'the Poxe.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What? the French Poxe?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The French Poxe! our Poxe: S'blood wee haue 'hem in as good forme as then man: what?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
Let me perish, but thou art a Villaine: was your new-created
Gallant there with you? Sogliardo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
