sp.p: O Porpuse, hang him, no: hee's a Lieger at Hornes Ordinarie yonder: his villanous Ganimede and hee ha'been droning a Tabacco Pipe there, euer sin' yesterday noone.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Who? Signior Tripartite, that would giue my Dogge the Whiffse?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I, hee: they haue hir'd a chamber and all priuat to practise in, for the making of the Patoun, the Receit Reciprocall, and a number of other mysteries, not yet extant. I brought some dosen or twentie Gallants this morning to view'hem (as you'ld doe a piece of Perspectiue) in at a key-hole; and there we might see Sogliardo sit in a Chaire, holding his snowt vp like a Sow vnder an Apple-tree, while th'other open'd his Nostrills with a Poking-sticke, to giue the smoake a more free deliuerie. They had spit some three or fourescore ounces betweene 'hem, afore we came away.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How! spit three or fourscore ounces?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, and preseru'd it in Porrengers, as a Barber does his Blood when he pricks a veine.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Out Pagan; how dost thou pricke the Vaine of thy friend?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Friend? Is there any such foolish thing i'the world? ha? S'lid I ne're rellisht it yet.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Thy Humor is the more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No not a whit Signior: Tut, a man must keepe time in all: I can oyle my tongue when I meet him next, and looke with a good slicke forehead; 'twill take away all soyle of Suspicion, and that's inough: what Lynceus can see my heart? Pish, the title of a Friend, it's a vaine idle thing, only venerable among fooles: you shall not haue one that has any opinion of wit affect it.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Saue you good Sir Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Signior Deliro! Welcome.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Pray you sir, did you see Master Fastidius Briske? I heard he was to meet your Worship here.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: You heard no Figment sir, I doe expect him euery minute my Watch strikes.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: There's a fellow now, lookes like one of the Patricians of Sparta, mary his wit's after ten i'the hundred. A good Bloud-hound, a close mouth'd Dog, hee followes the sent well, marry hee's at a fault now me thinks.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I should wonder at that Creature is free from the daunger of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O I cannot abide these limmes of Sattin, or rather Sathan indeed, that 'll walke (like the children of darkenesse) all day in a melancholy shop, with their pockets full of Blankes, readie to swallow vp as many poore vnthrifts, as come within the verge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: So: and what hast thou for him that is with him now?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O (Damne me) Immortalitie, I'le not meddle with him, the pure Element of Fire, all Spirit, Extraction.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How Carlo? ha, what is he man?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A scholler, Macilente, doe you not know him? a lanke rawbon'd Anatomie, he walks vp and down like a charg'd Musket, no man dares encounter him: that's his Rest there.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: His Rest? why has he a forked head?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Pardon me, that's to be suspended, you are too quick, too apprehensiue.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Troth (now I think on't) I'le defer it til some other time.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Gods-pretious, not by any meanes Signior, you shall not loose this opportunitie, he will be here presently now.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Yes faith Macilente, 'tis best. For looke you sir, I shall so exceedingly offend my wife in't, that—

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Your wife? now for shame loose these thoughts, and become the master of your own spirits. Should I (if I had a wife) suffer my self to be thus passionatly caried (to and for) with the streame of her Humort and neglect my deepest affairs, to serue her affections? Sbloud I would geld my selfe first.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O but Signior, had you such a wife as mine is, you wold—

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p:
Such a wife: Now God hate mee sir, if euer I discern'd
any wonder in your wife yet, with all the Speculation I haue: I haue seene some that ha'beene thought fairer than she, in my time; and I haue seene those, ha'not beene altogether so tall, esteem'd proper women; and I haue seen lesse Noses grow vpon sweeteer Faces, that haue done very well too in my judgemment: but in good faith Signior for all this, the Gentlewoman is a good prettie prowd hard-fauour'd thing, mary not so peerlessely to be doted vpon, I must confesse: nay be not angrie.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Well sir( how euer you please to forget your selfe) I haue not deseru'd to be thus plai'd vpon, but henceforth, pray you forbear my house, for I can but faintly endure the sauor of his breath at my table, that shal thus jade me for my courtesies.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Nay then Signior, let me tell you, your wife is no proper woman by Iesu, and I suspect her honestie, that's more, which you may likewise suspect (if you please:) doe you see? Ile vrge you to nothing against your appetite, but if you please, you may suspect it.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Good sir? Now Horne vpon Horne pursue thee, thou blind egregious Dotard.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O you shall heare him speake like Enuie. Signior Macilente, you saw Mounsieur Briske lately? I heard you were with him at the Court.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I Buffone, I was with him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And how is hee respected there? (I know youle deale ingeniously with us) is he made of amongst the sweeter sort of gallants?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Faith I, his Ciuet and his casting glasse,
Haue helpt him to a place amongst the rest,
And there his Seniors giue him good sleight lookes,
After their Garbe, smile, and salute in French
With some new complement.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What is this all?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Why say, that they should shew the frothie foole,
Such grace as they pretend comes from the heart,
He had a mightie wind-fall out of doubt.
Why all their Graces are not to doe Grace
To vertue, or desert: but to ride both
With their guilt Spurres quite breathlesse from themselues.
'Tis now esteem'd Precisianisme in wit;
And a Disease in Nature to be kind
Toward Desert, to Loue, or seeke good Names:
Who feeds with a Good name? who thriues with louing?
Who can prouide feast for his owne desires,
With seruing others? ha, ha, ha:
'Tis follie by our wisest worldlings prou'd
(If not to gaine by loue) to be belou'd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How like you him? is't not a good spitefull slaue? ha?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Shrewd, shrewd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Damme me, I could eat his flesh now: Deuine sweet villaine.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay, pr'y thee leaue: what's he there?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Who? this i'the starcht Beard? it's the dull stiffe Knight Puntarvolo man; hee's to trauaile now presently: hee has a good knottie wit, marry he carries little on't out of the land with him.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: He puts it forth in venter, as he does his money; vpon the returne of a Dog and Cat.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Is this hee?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, this is hee; a good tough Gentleman: he looks like a Chine of Brawne at Shrouetide, out of date, and readie to take his leaue: or a drie Poule of Ling vpon Easter-eue, that has furnisht the Table all Lent, as hee has done the Cittie this last Vacation.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Come, you'le neuer leaue your stabbing Simile's: I shall ha' you aiming at me with 'hem by and by, but—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, renounce me then: pure, honest, good Deuill, I loue thee aboue the loue of women; I could e'en melt in Admiration of thee now: Gods so, looke here man; Sir Dagonet and his Squire.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p:
Saue you my deare Gallanto's. nay, come approach,
good Caualier: pr'y thee (sweet Knight) know this Gentleman, hee's one that it pleases me to vse as my good friend and companion; and therefore doe him good offices: I beseech you Gentles, know him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sir (for Signior Sogliardos sake) let it suffice, I know you.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Why by Iesu, I thanke you Knight, and it shall suffice. Hearke you Sir Puntarvolo, you'ld little thinke it; hee's as resolute a piece of flesh as any's i'the world.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Vpon my Gentilitie sir: Carlo, a word with you; Doe you see that same fellow there?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What? Caualier Shift?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O, you know him; crie you mercie: before God, I think him the tallest man liuing within the walls of Europe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: The walls of Europe! take heed what you say Signior, Europe's a huge thing within the walls.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Tut, (and 'twere as huge againe) I'ld justifie what I speake. S'lid he swagger'd e'en now in a place where we were: I neuer saw a man doe it more resolute.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay indeed swaggering is a good Argument of Resolution. Doe you heare this, Signior?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I, to my griefe. O that such muddie Flags
For euery drunken florish, should atchieue
The name of Manhood; whil'st true perfect Valour
(Hating to shew it selfe) goes by despis'd.
Sbloud, I doc know now (in afaire just cause)
I dare doe more than hee; a thousand times:
Why should not they take knowledge of this? ha?
And giue my worth allowance before his?
Because I cannot swagger. Now the Poxe
Light on your Pickt-Hatch prowesse.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p:
Why I tell you Sir, he has been the only Bid-stand that euer was, kept New-Market, Salisburie Plaine, Hockley i'the hole, Gads-Hill; all the high places of any Request: hee has had his Mares and his Geldings hee, ha' been worth fortie, threescore,
a hundred pound a Horse, would ha' sprung you ouer hedge and ditch like your Greyhound: hee has done fiue hundred Robberies in his time, more or lesse, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What? and scapt?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Scapt! yfaith I: he has broken the jayle when hee has been in yrons, and yrons; and been out, and in againe; & out, and in; fortie times and not so few, hee.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: A fit Trumpet to proclaime such a person.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But can this be possible?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: why 'tis nothing sir, when a man giues his Affections to it.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Good Pylades discourse a Robberie or two, to satisfie these Gentlemen of thy worth.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me my deare Orestes: Causes haue their Quiddits, and 'tis ill jesting with Bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? Pylades and Orestes?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I, he is my Pylades, and I am his Orestes: how like you the conceit?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, it's an old stale Enterlude deuise: No, I'le giue you Names my selfe: looke you, he shal be your Iudas, and you shal be his Elder tree to hang on.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay rather, let him be Captaine Pod, and this his Motion; for he does nothing but Shew him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Excellent: or thus; you shall be Holden, and hee your camell.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: You doe not meane to ride Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Faith let me end it for you Gallants: you shall be his Countenance, and he your Resolution.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Troth that's prettie: how say you Caualier, shalt be so?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, I, most voices.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Faith I am eas'ly yeelding to any good Impressions:

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Then giue hands good Resolution.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Masse he cannot say good Countenance now (properly) to him againe.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Yes, by an Ironie.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O sir, the countenance of Resolution should, as hee's altogither grim and vnpleasant.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good houres make Musicke with your mirth Gentlemen, and keepe time to your humors: how now Carlo?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Monsieur Briske! many a long looke haue I extended for you sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good faith I must craue pardon; I was inuited this morning ere I was out of my bedde, by a Beuie of Ladies, to a Banquet: whence it was almost one of Hercules Labors for me to come away, but that the respect of my promise did so preuaile with me: I know they'le take it verie ill, especially one that gaue me this Bracelet of her Haire but ouer night, and this Pearle another gaue me from her forehead, Mary she— what? are the Writings readie?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I will send my man to know. Sirrah, goe you to the Notaries, and learne if he be readie: leaue the Dog sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: And how does my rare qualified friend Sogliardo? oh Signior Macilente! by these eyes I saw you not, I had saluted you sooner else on my troth: I hope sir I may presume vpon you that you will not divulge my late cheeke, or disgrace indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: You may sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: S'heart hee knowes some notorious jest by this Gull, that he hath him so obsequious.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Monsieur Fastidius, doe you see this fellow there? does hee not looke like a Clowne? would you thinke there's any thing in him?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Any thing in him? beshrow me, I; the fellow hath a good ingenious face.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: By this Element, hee is an ingenious tall man as euer swaggerd about London: hee and I call Countenance & Resolution, but his name is Caualier Shift.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Caualier, you knew Signior Clog, that was hang'd for the robberie at Harrow on the hill?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Knew him Sir! why 'twas hee gaue all the directions for the Action.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How? was't your Project sir?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me Countenance, you doe me some wrong to make that publicke, which I imparted to you in priuat.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Gods will, here are none but friends Resolution.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: That's all one; things of Consequence must haue their respects, where, how, and to whome. Yes sir, he shewed himselfe a true Clogge in the Coherence of that affaire sir; for if he had manag'd matters as they were corroborated to him, it had been better for him by a fortie or fiftie score of pounds sir, and hee himselfe might ha' liu'd (in despight of Fate) to haue fedde on Woodcockes with the rest: but it was his heauie fortunes to sinke poore Clogge, and therefore talke no more of him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: why, had hee more Agents then?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O God sir; I, there were some present there, that were the nine Worthies to him yfaith.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I sir, I can satisfie you at more conuenient conference: but (for mine owne part) I haue now reconcil'd my selfe to other courses, and professe a liuing out of my other qualities.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay, he has left all now (I assure you) and is able to liue like a Gentleman by his Qualitie. By this Dogge, hee has the most rare gift in Tabacco that euer you knew.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: S'heart, hee keeps more adoe with this Monster, than euer Bankes did with his Horse, or the Fellow with the Elephant.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Hee will hang out his Picture shortly in a cloath, you shall see.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O, hee do's manage a quarrell the best that euer you saw, for Termes and Circumstances.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good faith Signior (now you speake of a quarrell) I'le acquaint you with a difference that happened betweene a Gallant and my selfe: sir Puntarvolo, you know him if I should name him; Signior Luculento.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Luculento! what inauspicious chaunce interpos'd it selfe betwixt your two loues?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
Faith sir, the same that sundred Agamemnon and great Thetis son; but let the cause escape Sir: He sent me a challenge (mixt with some few braues) which I restor'd, and in fine wee met. Now indeed Sir (I must tell you) he did offer at first very desperatly, but without judgement: for looke you sir. I cast
my selfe into this figure: now he, comes violently on, and withall advancing his Rapier to strike, I thought to haue took his arme (for he had left his whole body to my election, and I was sure he could not recouer his guard) Sir, I mist my purpose in his arme, rasht his doublet sleeue, ran him close by the left cheeke, and through his haire: He again lights me here, I had a gold Cable hatband then new come vp, (which I wore about a murrey French Hat I had) cuts my Hatband (and yet it was Massie, gold-Smithes worke) cuts my brimmes, which by good fortune (being thicke embrodered with gold twist, and Spangles) disapointed the force of the blow: Neuerthelesse it graz'd on my shoulder, takes mee away sixe purles of an Italian cut-worke Band I wore, cost me three pounds in the exchaunge but three daies before.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: This was a straunge encounter.

sp.speaker: Fastid.
sp.p: Nay you shall heare sir, with this wee both fell out and breath'd: Now (vpon the second signe of his assault) I betooke mee to the former manner of my defence; hee (on the other side) abandon'd his bodie to the same daunger as before, and followes mee still with blowes. But I (being loth to take the deadly advauntage that lay before mee of his left side) made a kind of stramazoun, ran him vp to the hilts, through the Doublet, through the Shirt, and yet mist the skin. He (making a reuerse blow) fals vpon my emboss'd girdle (I had throwne off the hangers a little before) strikes off a skirt of a thick lac't Sattin Doublet I had (lin'd with some foure Taffataes) cuts of two panes embrodered with Pearle, rents through the drawings out of Tyssow, enters the linings, and skips the flesh.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I wonder he speakes not of his wrought Shirt.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
Here (in the opinion of mutuall dammage) we paus'd: but (ere I proceed) I must tell you Signior, that (in this last encounter) not hauing leisure to put off my siluer Spurres, one of the rowels catcht hold of the ruffle of my Boot, and (being Spanish leather, and subject to teare) ouerthrowes
me, rends me two paire of silke stockings (that I put on being somewhat a raw morning, a Peach colour and another) and strikes me some halfe inch deepe into the side of the Calfe; He (seeing the bloud come) presently takes horse and away. I (hauing bound vp my wound with a peece of my wrought Shirt)

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O comes it there?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Rid after him, and (lighting at the court gate both together) embrac'd and marcht hand in hand vp into the Presence.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, by this we can gesse what apparrell the Gentleman wore.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: 'Fore God it was a designment begun with much resolution, maintain'd with as much prowesse, and ended with more humanitie. How now, what saies he?

sp.speaker: Seruing.
sp.p: The Notarie saies hee is readie sir, he staies but your Worships pleasure.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come wee will goe to him Mounsieur. Gentlemen shall wee entreat you to be witnesses.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: You shall entreat mee sir, come Resolution.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I follow you good Countenance.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come Signior, come, come.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: O, that there should be fortune
To cloth these men, so naked in desert,
And that the iust Storme of a wretched life,
Beats'hem not ragged for their wretched soules,
And since as fruitlesse, euen as blacke as coales.

sp.speaker: Mitis.
sp.p:
Why but Signior, how comes it that Fungoso appear'd
not with his sisters intelligence to Briske.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Mary long of the euill Angels that shee gaue him, who haue indeed tempted the good simple youth to follow the taile of the Fashion, and neglect the imposition of his friends. Behold here hee comes, very Worshipfully attended, and with good varietie.

div.head: SCENA QUARTA.
div.stage: Enter Fungoso with Taylor, Shoe-maker, and Haberdasher.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.l: Gramercie good Shoe-maker, I'le put too strings my selfe.
Now Sir, let mee see, what must you haue for this Hat?

sp.speaker: Haber.
sp.p: Here's the bill, sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: How doest become me, well?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Excellent Sir, as euer you had any Hat in your life.

sp.speaker: Haber.
sp.p: Nay faith Sir, the Hat's as good as any man i' this towne can serue you. And will maintaine Fashion as long, ne're trust me for a groat else.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Do's it apply well to my sute?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Exceeding well sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: How lik'st thou my suit Haberdasher?

sp.speaker: Hab.
sp.p: By my troth sir 'tis very rarely well made, I neuer saw a sute sit better I can tell on.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Nay, we haue no Art to please our friends, we.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Here Haberdasher tell this same.

sp.speaker: Haberdasher.
sp.p: Good faith sir, it makes you haue an excellent bodie.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay (beleeue me) I thinke I haue as good a bodie in cloths as another.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: You lacke points to bring your apparrell together.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I'le haue points anone: how now? is't right?

sp.speaker: Hab.
sp.p: Faith sir 'tis too little, but vpon farther hopes. Good morrow to you sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Farewell good Haberdasher, well now maister Smp let me see your bill.

sp.speaker: Mit. Cord.
sp.p: Mee thinkes he discharges his followers too thicke, O therin he saucily imitates some Great man. I warrant you though he turnes off them, he keepes this Taylor in place of a Page to follow him still.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: This Bill is very reasonable in faith, harke you maister Snip. Troth sir I am not altogether so well furnisht at this present, as I could wish I were: but— If you'le doe me the fauour to take part in hand, you shall haue all I haue by Iesu.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: And but giue me credite for the rest, till the beginning of the next Tearme.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: O Lord sir—

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: 'Fore God and by this light I'le pay you to the vtmost, and acknowledge my selfe very deepely engag'd to you by this hand.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Why how much haue you there Sir?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Marry I haue here foure Angels, and fifteene shillings of White money, it's all I haue as' hope to be sau'd.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: You will not faile mee at the next Tearme with the rest.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: No and I doe, pray God I bee hang'd. Let me neuer breath againe vpon this mortall Stage, as the Philosopher cals it. By this aire, and (as I am a Gentleman) I'le hold.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: He were an yron-hearted fellow in my judgement, that would not credite him vpon these monstrous others.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p:
Well sir, I'le not sticke with any Gentleman for a
trifle: you know what 'tis remaines?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I sir, and I giue you thankes in good faith, O God how happie am I made in this good fortune. Well, now I'le goe seeke out Mounsieur Briske. Gods so, I haue forgot Ribband for my shoes; and points. S'lid what lucke's this? how shall I doe? Maister Snippe, pray let me reduct some two or three shillings for points and Ribband, by Iesu I haue vtterly disfurnisht my selfe in the default of memorie, pray, le' mee bee beholding to you, it shall come home i'the bill beleeue mee.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Faith sir, I can hardly depart with money, but I'le take vp and send you by my boy presently. What colour'd Ribband would you haue?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: What you shall thinke meet i'your judgement Sir to my sute.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Well, I'le send you some presently.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: And points too sir?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And points too sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Good Lord how shall I studie to deserue this kindnes of you sir. Pray let your youth make hast, for I should haue done a businesse an hower since, that I doubt I shall come too late. Now in good truth I am exceeding prowd of my sute.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Do you obserue the plunges that this poore Gallant is put too (Signior) to purchase the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I, and to be still a Fashion behind with the world, that's the sport.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Stay: O here they come from seal'd and deliuer'd.

div.head: SCENA QUINTA.
div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Fastidius Briske, seruing men with the Dog.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Well now my whole venter is forth, I will resolue to depart shortly.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith sir Puntaruolo goe to the Court, and take leaue of the Ladies first.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I care not if it bee this afternoones labour. Where is Carlo?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Carlo, Sogliardo, Shift, and Macilente.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Faith Gallants, I am persuading this Gentleman to turne Courtier, he is a man of faire Reuenue, and his estate will beare the charge well, besides for his other gifts of the mind, or so, why, they are as Nature lent him 'hem, pure, simple, without any Artificiall drug or mixture of these two thredbare beggerly qualities, Learning and Knowledge, and therefore the more accommodate and Genuine. Now for the life it selfe—

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: O, the most Celestiall, and full of wonder and delight that can bee imagin'd Signior, beyond all thought and apprehension of Pleasure. A man liues there in that deuine Rapture, that he will thinke himselfe i' the third Heauen for the time, and loose all sence of Mortalitie whatsoeuer; when hee shall behold such glorious (and almost immortall) beauties, heare such Angelicall and Harmonious voices, discourse with such flowing and Ambrosian spirits, whose wits as suddaine as Lightning, and humorous as Nectar; Oh: it makes a man all Quintessence and Flame, and lifts him vp (in a moment) to the very Christall Crowne o'the skie, where (houering in the strength of his Imagination) he shall behold all the delights of the Hesperides, the Insulae Fortunatae, Adonis gardens, Tempe, or what else (confin'd within the amplest verge of Poesie) to bee meere Vmbrae, and imperfect Figures, confer'd with the most essentiall felicitie of your Court.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Wel this ENCOMION was not extemporall, it came too perfectly off.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Besides Sir, you shall neuer need to goe to a hothouse, you shall sweat there with courting your mistresse, or loosing your money at Primero, as well as in all the Stoues in Flaunders.
Mary this sir, you must euer be sure to carrie a good strong perfume about you, that your mistresse Dog may smell you out amongst the rest; and (in making loue to her) neuer feare to be out: for you may haue a pipe of Tabacco, or a base Violl shall hang o'the wall of purpose, will put you in presently. The Tricks your Resolution has taught you in Tabacco, (the Whiffe, and those sleights) will stand you in very good Ornament there?

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: I, to some perhaps: but, and hee should come to my Mistresse with Tabacco (this Gentleman knowes) shee'ld replie vpon him yfaith. Oh (by this bright sunne) shee has the most acute, readie, and facetious wit, that— tut there's no spirit able to stand her. You can report it Signior, you haue seene her?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Then can he report no lesse out of his judgement, I assure him.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Troth I like her well ynough, but shee's too selfe-conceited me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I indeed, shee's a little too selfe-conceited, and 'twere not for that Humor, she were the most to bee admir'd Ladie in the world.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Indeed it is a Humor that takes from her other excellencies.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why it may easily bee made to forsake her in my thought.

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: Easily Sir? then are all impossibilities easie.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: You conclude too quicke vpon me Signior, what will you say if I make it so perspicuously appeare now, that your selfe shall confesse nothing more possible.

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: Marry I will say, I will both applaud you, and admire you for it.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: And I will second him.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why I'le shew you Gentlemen, Carlo come hether.

div.stage: Macilente, Carlo, Puntarvolo, and Briske, whisper.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Good faith I haue a great Humor to the Court, what thinkes my Resolutions? shall I aduenture?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Troth Countenance, as you please; the Place is a place of good Reputation and Capacitie.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O, my trickes in Tabacco (as Carlo saies) will shew excellent there.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Why you may goe with these Gentlemen now, and see fashions; and after, as you shall see Correspondence.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: You say true. You will goe with me Resolution?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I will meet you Countenance, about three or foure of Clocke, but, to say to goe with you I cannot, for (as I am Apple Iohn) I am to goe before the Cocatrice you saw this morning, and therefore pray, present me excus'd good Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Farewell good Resolution, but faile not to meet.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: As I liue.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Admirably excellent.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: If you can but persuade Sogliardo to the Court, there's all now.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O let me alone, that's my taske:

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Now by Iesu Macilente, it 's aboue measure excellent: 'twill bee the onely courtly exploit that euer prou'd Courtier ingenious.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Vpon my soule it puts the Ladie quite out of her Humor, and we shall laugh with judgement.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come, the Gentleman was of himselfe resolu'd to goe with you, afore I mou'd it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why then Gallants, you two and Carlo goe afore to prepare the jeast: Sogliardo and I will come some while after you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Pardon me, I am not for the Court.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That's true: Carlo comes not at the Court indeed well, you shall leaue it to the facultie of Mounsieur Briske, and my selfe; vpon our liues wee will mannage it happily. Carlo shall bespeake supper at the Miter against wee come backe: where we will meet, and dimple our cheeks with laughter at the successe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, but will you all promise to come.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: My selfe shall manfrede it for them: he that failes, let his Reputation lie vnder the lash of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Gods so', looke who comes here.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: What, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Vncle, God saue you; did you see a Gentleman, one Monsieur Briske? a Courtier, he goes in such a Sute as I doe.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Here is the Gentleman Nephew, but not in such a Sute.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Another Sute!

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How now Nephew?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Would you speake to mee Sir?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I, when he has recouered himselfe: poore Poll.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Some Rosa-solis.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: How now Signior?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: I am not well Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why this it is, to dog the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay come Gentlemen, remember your affaires; his disease is nothing but the Fluxe of Apparell.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sirs, returne to the lodging, keepe the Cat safe; I'le be the Dogs Guardian my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nephew, will you goe to the Court with vs; these Gentlemen and I are for the Court: nay be not so Melancholly.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: By Gods lid I think no man in Christendome has that rescally fortune that I haue.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Faith your Sute is well enough Signior.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Nay, not for that I protest; but I had an errand to Monsieur Fastidius, and I haue forgot it.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why goe along to the Court with vs, and remember it, come. Gentlemen, you three take one Boat, and Sogliardo and I will take another: we shall be there instantly.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Content: good Sir vouchsafe vs your pleasance.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Farewell Carlo; remember.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I warrant you: would I had one of Kemps shooes to throw after you.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Good Fortune will close the eyes of our jest, feare not: and we shall frollicke.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: This Macilente Signior begins to bee more sociable on a suddaine me thinkes, than he was before, there 's some Portent in't, I beleeue.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O hee's a fellow of a strange Nature. Now do's hee (in this calme of his Humor) plot and store vp a world of malicious thoughts in his braine, till he is so full with 'hem, that you shall see the very Torrent of his Envie breake forth, and against the course of all their affections oppose it selfe so violently, that you will almost haue wonder to thinke how 'tis possible the current of their Dispositions shall receiue so quicke and strong an alteration.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I marry sir, this is that on which my Expectation has dwelt all this while: for I must tell you Signior (though I was loth to interrupt the Scene) yet I made it a question in mine owne priuate discourse, how hee should properly call it, Euerie man out of his Humor, when I saw all his Actors so strongly pursue and continue their Humors?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Why therein his Art appeares most full of lustre, and approcheth nearest the life, especially when in the flame and height of their Humors they are laid flat, it fils the eye better, and with more contentment. How tedious a sight were it to behold a prowd exalted tree lopt and cut downe by degrees, when it might be feld in a moment? and to set the Axe to it, before it came to that pride and fulnesse, were as not it haue it grow.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Well I shall long till I see this fall you talke of.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: To helpe your longing, Signior, let your imagination be swifter than a paire of Oares, and by this, suppose Puntarvolo, Briske, Fungoso, and the Dog, arriu'd at the court gate, and going vp to the great chamber. Macilente and Sogliardo, wee'le leaue them on the water till Possibilitie and Naturall meanes may land 'hem. Here come the Gallants, now prepare your Expectation.

div.head: SCENA PRIMA.
div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Fastidius Briske, Fungoso, and the Dog.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come Lordings. Signior you are sufficiently instructed.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Who I sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: No, this Gentleman. But stay, I take thought how to bestow my dog, he is no competent attendant for the Presence.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Masse that 's true in deed knight, you must not carrie him into the Presence.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I know it, and I (like a dull beast) forgot to bring one of my Cormorants to attend me.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why you're best leaue him at the Porters lodge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Not so: his worth is too well knowne amongst them, to be forth-comming.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Slight, how'll you doe then?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I must leaue him with one that is ignorant of his qualitie, if I will haue him to be safe. And see; Here comes one that will carrie coales, Ergo, will hold my Dogge. My honest friend, may I commit the tuition of this Dog to thy prudent care?

div.stage: Enter a Groome with a basket.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: You may if you please sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Pray thee let me find thee here at my returne: it shall not be long, till I will Ease thee of thy emploiment, and Please thee. Forth Gentles.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why, but will you leaue him with so slight command, and infuse no more charge vpon the fellow?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Charge? no, there weare no pollicie in that; that were to let him know the value of the Gem he holds, and so, to tempt fraile nature against her disposition. No, pray thee let thy Honestie be sweet and short.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
But heark you Gallants, and cheefely Monsieur Brisk, When wee come in eye-shot or presence of this Ladie, let
not other matters carrie vs from our Project: but (if wee can) single her forth to some place.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: And be not too suddaine, but let the deuise induce it selfe with good Circumstance: on.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Is this the way? good truth here be fine hangings.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: Honestie, Sweet and Short? mary it shall sir, doubt you not: for euen at this instant if one would giue me twentie pounds, I would not deliuer him; there's for the Sweet: but now, if any man come offer me but two-pence, he shall haue him; there's for the Short now. Sbloud, what a mad Humorous Gentleman is this to leaue his Dogge with me: I could runne away with him now and he were worth any thing: well, I pray God send him quickly againe.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Come on Signior, now prepare to Court this All-witted Ladie, most Naturally and like your selfe.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Faith and you say the word, I'le begin to her in Tabacco.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O, fie on't. no: you shall begin with, How does my sweet Ladie; or, Why are you so melancholly Madame? though she be very merrie, it's all one: be sure to kisse your hand often enough; pray for her health, and tell her, how more than most faire she is: Screw your face at' 'one side thus, & Protest; let her fleere and looke askaunce, and hide her Teeth with her Fanne, when shee laughes a fitte, to bring her into more matter; that's nothing: you must talke forward (though it be without sense, so it be without blushing) 'tis most Courtlike and well.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: But shall I not vse Tabacco at all?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O, by no meanes, 'twill but make your breath suspected; and that you vse it onely to confound the rankenesse of that.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay, I'le be aduis'd sir by my friends.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Gods my life, see where sir Puntars Dogge is.

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: I would the Gentleman would returne for his follower here, I'le leaue him to his fortunes else.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: S'heart, 'twere the onely true jest in the world to poison him now: ha? by Gods will I'le doe it, if I could but get him of the fellow. Signior Sogliardo, walke aside, and thinke vpon some deuise to entertaine the Ladie with.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: So I doe sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: How now mine honest friend? whose Dog-keeper art thou?

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: Dog-keeper sir? I hope I scorne that yfaith.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why? do'st thou not keepe a Dogge?

sp.speaker: Groome.
sp.p: Sir, now I doe, and now I doe not: I thinke this be Sweet and Short: make me his Dog-keeper?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: This is excellent aboue expectation: nay stay sir, you'ld be trauailing; but I'le giue you a Dramme shall shorten your voyage: here: so sir, I'le be bold to take my leaue of you: now to the Turkes Court in the Deuils name, for you shal neuer go on Gods name. [Kicks him out. ]Sogliardo, come.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I ha' 't yfaith now, will sting it.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Take heed you leese it not Signior, ere you come there: preserue it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How like you this first exploit of his?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, a piece of true Enuie, but I expect the issue of the other deuise.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Here they come, will make it appeare.

div.head: SCENA SECUNDA.
div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Sauiolina, Fastidius Briske, Fungoso.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Why I thought Sir Puntarvolo, you had been gone your Voyage?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Deare, and most Amiable Ladie, your Diuine Beauties doe bind me to those Offices, that I cannot depart when I would.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p:
'Tis most Courtlike spoken sir; but how might we doe
to haue a sight of your Dog and Cat?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: His Dogge's in the Court, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: And not your Cat? how dare you trust her behind you Sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Troth Madame shee hath sore eyes, and shee doth keepe her Chamber: marry I haue left her vnder sufficient guard: there are two of my Hinds to attend her.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Ile giue you some Water for her eyes: when do you goe sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Certes sweet Ladie, I know not.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: He doth stay the rather Madame, to present your Acute judgement with so Courtly, and well-Parted a Gentleman, as yet your Ladiship hath neuer seene.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: What's hee, gentle Monsieur Briske? not that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No Lady, this is a Kinsman of Iustice Silence.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Pray' sir, giue me leaue to report him: hee's a Gentleman (Ladie) of that rare and admirable facultie, as (I protest) I know not his like in Europe: he is exceedingly Valiant, an excellent Scholler, and so exactly trauail'd, that hee is able in discourse, to deliuer you a Modell of any Princes Court in the world: 'speakes the Languages with that puritie of Phrase, and facilitie of Accent, that it breeds astonishment: his Wit, the most Exuberant, and (aboue wonder) pleasant, of all that euer entred the concaue of this care.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis most true Ladie; mary he is no such excellent proper man.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: His Trauailes haue chang'd his complexion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: O Sir Puntarvolo, you must thinke euery man was not borne to haue my Seruant Briskes feature.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: But that which transcends all, Ladie; he doth so Peerlessely imitate any manner of person for Gesture, Action, Passion, or what euer—

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I, especially a Rusticke or a Clowne Madam, that it is not possible for the sharpest-sighted wit (in the world) to discerne any sparkes of the Gentleman in him, when he does it.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: O Monsieur Briske, be not so Tyranous to confine all Wits within the compasse of your owne: Not find the sparks of a Gentleman in him, if he be a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: No in truth (sweet Ladie) I beleeue you cannot.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Doe you beleeue so? Why I can find sparkes of a Gentleman in you Sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I, he is a Gentleman Madam, and a Reueller.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Indeed I thinke I haue seene your Ladiship at our Reuels.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Like enough sir: but would I might see this wonder you talke of: may one haue a sight of him for any reasonable summe?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Yes Madam, he will arriue presently.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: What, and shall we see him Clowne it?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I faith (sweet Ladie) that you shall: see here he comes.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: This is hee; pray obserue him Ladie.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Beshrew me, he Clownes it properly indeed.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Nay, marke his Courtship.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How does my sweet Ladie; hote and moist? Beautifull and lustie? ha?

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Beautifull and it please you sir, but not lustie.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O ho Ladie; it pleases you to say so in truth: and how does my sweet Ladie; in health? Bonaroba, quaeso? que Novelles? que Novelles? Sweet creature.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: O excellent: why Gallants, is this hee cannot be Decipher'd? they were very bleare-witted yfaith that could not discerne the Gentleman in him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: But doe you, in earnest Ladie?

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Doe I sir? why if you had any true Court-judgement in the carriage of his eye, and that inward power that forms his countenance, you might perceiue his counterfaiting as cleere as the noone day: Alas; Nay if you would haue tried my Wit indeed, you should neuer haue told me hee was a Gentleman, but presented him for a true Clowne indeed; and then haue seene if I could haue Decipher'd him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Fore God, her Ladiship sayes true (Knight:) but does he not affect the Clowne most naturally, Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O, shee cannot but affirme that, out of the Bountie of her Iudgement.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Nay out of doubt hee does well, for a Gentleman to imitate; but I warrant you, he becomes his Naturall carriage of the Gentleman, much better than his Clownerie.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis straunge in truth, her Ladiship should see so farre into him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I, is't not.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Faith as easily as may bee: not Decipher him, quoth you?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Good sadnesse, I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why, has shee Decipher'd him, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O most miraculously, and beyond Admiration.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Shee hath giuen most infallible signes of the Gentleman in him, that's certaine.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Why Gallants, let me laugh at you a little: was this your deuice, to try my judgement in a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay Ladie, doe not scorne vs, though you haue this gift of Perspicacie aboue others: What if he should be no Gentleman now, but a Clowne indeed Ladie?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How thinke you of that? would not your Ladiship be out of your Humour?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O, but she knowes it is not so.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: What if he were not a man, yee may as well say? nay if your Worships could Gull me so indeed, you were wiser than you are taken for.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: In good faith Ladie, hee is a verie perfect Clowne, both by Father and Mother: that I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: O Sir, you are very pleasurable.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay, do but looke on his Hand, and that shall resolue you: Looke you Ladie, what a Palme here is.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Tut, that was with holding the Plough.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p:
The Plough! did you discerne any such thing in him
Madame?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith no, she saw the Gentleman as bright as at noon-day shee: she decipher'd him at first.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Troth I am sorrie your Ladiships sight should be so suddainly strooke.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: O, you're goodly Beagles!

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: What, is shee gone?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay stay sweet Ladie; Que Novelles, Que Novelles.

sp.speaker: Saui.
sp.p: Out, you foole you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Shee's out of her Humor yfaith.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Nay, let's follow it while 'tis hot Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come, on mine Honour wee'le make her blush in the Presence: my splene is great with laughter.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Your laughter will be a child of a feeble life I beleeue sir. Come Signior, your lookes are too dejected me thinkes: why mixe you not mirth with the rest?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: By Gods will this Sute frets me at the Soule. I'le haue it alter'd to morrow sure.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I am come to the Court to meet with my Countenance Sogliardo: poore men must be glad of such Countenance, when they can get no better. Wel, Need may insult vpon a man, but it shall neuer make him despaire of Consequence: The world will say, 'tis base; tush, base! 'tis base to liue vnder the earth, not base to liue aboue it, by any meanes.

div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Fastidius, Sogliardo, Fungoso, Macilente.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: The poore Lady is most miserably out of her Humour yfaith.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: There was neuer so wittie a jeast broken at the Tilt, of all the Court wits christen'd.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O, this applause taints it fowly.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I thinke I did my part in Courting. O Resolution!

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Aye me, my Dogge.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Where is hee?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Gods pretious, go seeke for the fellow, good Signior.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Here, here I left him.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why none was here when we came in now, but Caualier Shift, enquire of him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Did you see Sir Puntarvolos Dogge here Cavalier, since you came?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: His Dog sir? he may looke his Dog sir; I see none of his Dog sir.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Vpon my life hee hath stol'ne your Dog sir, and been hir'd to it by some that haue ventur'd with you; you may gesse by his peremptorie answeres.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Not vnlike; for he hath been a notorious theefe by his owne confession. Sirrah, where's my Dogge?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Charge me with your Dog sir? I ha' none of your Dog Sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Villaine, thou lyest.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Lie sir? S'blood y'are but a man sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Rogue and Thiefe, restore him.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Take heed sir Puntarvolo what you doe; hee'le beare no coales I can tell you (of my word.)

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: This is rare.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: It's mar'le he stabs you not: by this Light, he hath stab'd fortie for fortie times lesse matter, I can tell you, of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I will make thee stoupe, thou Abject.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Make him stoupe sir! Gentlemen pacifie him or hee'le be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Is he so tall a man?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Tall a man? if you loue his life stand betwixt 'hem: make him stoupe!

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: My Dog Villaine, or I will hang thee: thou hast confest robberies, and other Fellonious acts to this Gentleman thy Countenance.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I'le beare no witnesse.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: And without my Dog I will hang thee, for them.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: What? kneele to thine enemie?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me good sir; God is my Iudge I neuer did Robberie in all my life.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O sir Puntarvolo, your Dog lies giuing vp the ghost in the wood-yard.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: S'blood is he not dead yet?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O, my Dogge borne to disastrous fortune! pray you conduct me sir.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How? did you neuer doe any robberie in your life?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O this is good: so he swore sir.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I, I heard him. And did you sweare true sir?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I (as God shall haue part of my soule Sir) I ne're rob'd any man I; neuer stood by the high way side sir, but only said so, because I would get my self a name & be counted a tall man.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Now out base Viliaco: Thou my Resolution? I thy Countenance? By this light Gentlemen, he hath confest to me the most inexorable companie of Robberies, and damn'd himselfe that he did 'hem; you neuer heard the like: out skoundrell out, follow me no more I commaund thee: out of my sight, goe, hence, speake not: I will not heare thee; away Camouccio.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O, how I do feed vpon this now, and fat my self? here were a couple vnexpectedly dishumor'd: well, by this time I hope sir Puntarvolo and his Dog are both out of Humor to trauaile: nay Gentlemen, why do you not seeke out the Knight, and comfort him? our Supper at the Mitre must of necessitie hold to night, if you loue your Reputations.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Fore God I am so Melancholly for his Dogs disaster, but I'le goe.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Faith and I may goe too, but I know I shall be so Melancholly.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Tush, Melancholly? you must forget that now, and remember you lie at the mercie of a Furie: Carlo will racke your sinews asunder, and raile you to dust if you come not.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O then their feare of Carlo be like, makes them hold their meeting.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I, here he comes: conceiue him but to bee enter'd the Mitre, and 'tis enough.

div.head: SCENA TERTIA.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Holla: where be these Shot-sharkes?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: By and by: you're welcome good Master Buffone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Where's George? call me George hither quickly.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What wine please you haue Sir? I'le draw you that's neat Master Buffone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Away Neophite, doe as I bid; bring my deare George to me: Masse here he comes.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Welcome Master Carlo.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What's Supper readie, George?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: I sir, almost: will you haue the cloath laid, Master Carlo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, what else: are none of the Gallants come yet?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: None yet sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Stay, take me with you George: let me haue a good fat Loyne of Porke laid to the fire presently.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: It shall sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And withall, heare you? draw me the biggest shaft you haue out of the But you wot of: away, you know my meaning George, quicke.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Done sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Sbloud, I neuer hungred so much for thing in my life, as I doe to know our Gallants successe at the Court: now is that leane Bald-rib Macilente, that salt Villaine, plotting some mischieuous deuise, and lyes a soaking in their frothy Humors like a dry crust, till he has drunke 'hem all vp: could the Kecks but hold vp's eyes at other mens happinesse in any reasonable proportion, S'lid the slaue were to be loued next Heauen, aboue Honour, Wealth, rich Fare, Apparell, Wenches, all the delights of the Belly, and the Groine, whateuer.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Here Master Carlo.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Is't right, Boy?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I sir, I assure you 'tis right.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Well said my deare George, depart: Come, my small Gymblet, you in the false scabberd, away; so: Now to you sir Burgomaster, let's tast of your Bountie.

div.stage: Puts forth the Drawer and shuts the dore.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What, will he deale vpon such quantities of Wine alone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You shall perceiue that sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I marry sir, here's puritie: O George, I could bite off thy nose for this now: Sweet Rogue, hee has drawne Nectar, the very Soule of the Grape: I'le wash my temples with some on't presently, and drinke some halfe a score draughts; 'twill heat the Braine, kindle my Imagination, I shall talke nothing but Crackers and Fire-worke to night. So sir; Please you to be here sir, and I here: So.

div.stage: He sets the two cups asunder, and first drinkes with the one, and pledges with the other.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: This is worth the obseruation, Signior.

sp.speaker: Carl. 1 cup.
sp.p: Now sir, here's to you; and I present you with so much of my loue.

sp.speaker: 2 Cup.
sp.p: I take it kindly from you Sir. (Drinks )And will return you the like proportion: but withall sir, remembring the merrie night we had at the Countesses; you know where sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Cup.
sp.p: By Iesu you doe put me in mind now of a very necessarie office, which I wil propose in your pledge sir: The health of that Honorable Countesse, and the sweet Ladie that sat by her sir.

2 I do vail to it with reuerence. (Drinks. )2. And now Signior, with these Ladies, I'le be bold to mixe the health of your Diuine Mistresse. 1. Doe you know her sir? 2 O Lord sir, I, and in the respectfull memorie and mention of her, I could wish this Wine were the most pretious drugge in the world.
1 Good faith sir, you do honor mein 'texceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Whome should he personate in this, Signior?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Faith I know not sir, obserue, obserue him.

2 If it were the basest filth or mudde that runnes in the channell, I am bound to pledge it by God sir. (Drinks. )And now sir, here is againe a replenisht bowle sir, which I will reciprocally returne vpon you to the health of the Count Frugale. 1 The Count Frugales health sir? I'le pledge it on my knees by Iesu. 2 Will you sir? Ile drinke it on my knees then, by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Why this is strange.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha' you heard a better drunken Dialogue?

2 Nay, do me right Sir. 1 So I doe in good faith. 2 Good faith you doe not; mine was fuller. 1 Why by Iesu it was not. 2 By Iesu it was, and you doe lie. 1 Lie sir. 2 I Sir. 1 S'wounds you Rascall. 2 O, come, stabbe if you haue a mind to it. 1 Stabbe? dost thou thinke I dare not? [In his owne person.] Nay, I beseech you Gentlemen, what meanes this; nay looke, for shame respect your Reputations.

div.stage: Ouer-turnes Wine, Pot, Cuppes, and all.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why how now Carlo; what Humor's this?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O my good Mischiefe, art thou come? where are the rest? where are the rest?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith three of our Ordinance are burst.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Burst? how comes that?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith ouer-charg'd, ouer-charg'd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But did not the traine hold?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O yes, and the poore Ladie is irrecouerably blown vp.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why, but which of the Munition is miscarried? ha?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Imprimis, Sir Puntarvolo: next, the Countenance, and Resolution.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? how for thes loue of God?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Troth the Resolution is proou'd Recreant; the Countenance hath chang'd his Coppie; and the Passionate Knight, is shedding Funerall teares ouer his departed Dogge.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What's his Dogge dead?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Poison'd 'tis thought: mary how, or by whom, that's left for some Cunning woman heere o' the Banke-side to resolue: For my part, I know nothing, more than that wee are like to haue an exceeding Melancholly Supper of it.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: S'life, and I had purpos'd to be extraordinarily merry: I had drunke off a good Preparatiue of old Sacke here: but will they come, will they come?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: They will assuredly come: marry Carlo (as thou lou'st me) runne ouer 'hem all freely to night, and especially the Knight; spare no Sulphurous jest that may come out of that sweatie Forge of thine, but ply 'hem with all manner of Shot, Minion, Saker, Culverine, or any thing what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I warrant thee my deare Case of Petrionels, so I stand not in dread of thee, but that thou'lt second me.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why my good Germane Tapster, I will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What George. Lomtero, Lomtero, &c.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Did you call, Master Carlo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: More Nectar, George: Lomtero, &c.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Your meat's readie sir and your companie were come.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Is the Loine a Porke enough?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: I Sir, it is enough?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Porke? S'heart what dost thou with such a greasie Dish; I thinke thou dost Varnish thy face with the fat on't, it lookes so like a Glew-pot.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
True, my Raw-bon'd Rogue: and if thou would'st farce thy leane Ribs wth it too, they would not (like ragged Lathes) rub out so many Dublets as they do: but thou know'st not a good Dish, thou. O, it's the only nourishing meat in the world: No maruaile though that saucie stubborne Generation the Iewes, were forbidden it: for what would they ha' done, well pamper'd with fat Porke, that durst murmure
at their maker out of Garlicke and Onions. Sblood fed with it, the horion strummell patcht, Goggle-ey'd Grumble doryes, would ha' Gigantomachiz'd. Well said my sweet George, fill, fill.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: This sauours too much of Prophanation.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O servetur ad imum, qualis ab incepto processerit, & sibo constet. The necessitie of his vaine compels a tolleration: for, barre this, and dash him out of Humor before his time.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Tis an Axiome in Naturall Philosophie, What comes nearest the Nature of that it feeds, conuerts quicker to nourishment, and doth sooner essentiate. Now nothing in Flesh and Entrailes, assimulates or resembles Man more, than a Hog or Swine.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: True; and hee (to requite their courtesie) oftentimes d'offeth off his owne Nature, and puts on theirs; as when hee becomes as churlish as a Hogge, or as drunke as a Sow: but to your conclusion.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Marry I say, nothing resembling Man more than a Swine, it followes, nothing can be more nourishing: for indeed (but that it abhorres from our nice Nature) if we fed one vpon another, we should shoot vp a great deale faster, & thriue much better: I referre me to your Long-lane Cannibals, or such like: but since 'tis so contrarie; Porke, Porke; is your only feed.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: I take it your Deuill be of the same Diet; hee would ne're ha' desir'd to been incorporated into Swine else. O here comes the Melancholly messe: vpon 'hem Carlo, charge, charge.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Fore God sir Puntarvolo, I am sorie for your heauinesse; Bodie a mee, a shrewd mischaunce: why had you no Vnicorne horne, nor Bezars stone about you? ha?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sir, I would request you be silent.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay, to him againe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Take comfort good Knight, if your Cat ha' recouered
her Cataract, feare nothing; your Dogges mischaunce may be holpen.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Say how (sweet Carlo) for so God mend me, the poore Knights mones draw mee into fellowship of his misfortunes. But be not discouraged good sir Puntarvolo, I am content your aduenture shall be perform'd vpon your Cat.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: I beleeue you Musk-cod, I beleeue you, for rather than thou would'st make present repaiment, thou would'st take it vpon his owne bare returne from Callice.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay Gods life, hee'ld be content (so he were well rid out of his companie) to pay him fiue for one at his next meeting him in Paules. But for your Dogge, sir Puntar, if he be not out-right dead, there is a friend of mine a Quack-saluer, shall put life in him againe, that's certaine.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O no, that comes too late.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Gods pretious Knight, will you suffer this?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Drawer; get me a Candle and hard waxe presently.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I, and bring vp Supper; for I am so Melancholly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah Signior, where's your Resolution?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Resolution! hang him Rascall: O Carlo, if you loue me doe not mention him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why, how so? how so?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O the arrant'st Crocodile that euer Christian was acquainted with. By Iesu, I shall thinke the worse of Tabacco while I liue for his sake: I did thinke him to be as tall a man—

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay Buffone, the Knight, the Knight.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sblood, hee lookes like an Image carued out of Boxe, full of knots: his Face is (for all the world) like a Dutch purse with the mouth downward; his beard's the Tassels: and hee walkes (let me see) as Melancholly as one o'the Masters side in the Counter. Doe you heare sir Puntar?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sir, I doe entreat you no more, but enjoyne you to silence, as you affect your peace.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Nay but deare Knight vnderstand (here are none but friends, & such as wish you well) I would ha' you do this now; Fleame your Dog presently (but in any case keep the head) &
stuffe his skin well with straw, as you see these dead monsters at Bartholmew faire.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I shall be suddaine I tell you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Or if you like not that sir, get me somewhat a lesse dog and clap into the skin; here 's a slaue about the towne here, a Iew, one Yohan; or a fellow that makes Periwigs will glew it on artificially, it shall ne're bee discern'd; besides, 'twill be so much the warmer for the Hound to travell in you know.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Sir Puntarvolo, Sdeath can you be so patient?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Or thus Sir: you may haue (as you come through Germanie) a Familiar for little or nothing shall turn it selfe into the shape of your Dog, or any thing (what you will) for certaine howers: Gods my life knight, what do you meane? youle offer no violence, will you? Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sbloud you slaue, you Bandog you.

sp.speaker: Carlo.
sp.p: As you loue God, stay the enraged knight, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: By my knighthood, hee that stirres in his rescue, dies. Drawer be gone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I, are you houling, you Wolfe? Gentlemen, as you tender your liues, suffer no man to enter, till my reuenge bee perfect. Sirha Buffone, lie downe; make no exclamations, but downe; downe you Curre, or I will make thy blood flow on my Rapier hilts:

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Sweet knight hold in thy furie, and 'fore God I'le honour thee more than the Turke do's Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Downe (I say.) Whos's there?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Here's the Constable, open the dores.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Good Macilente.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Open no dore, if the Adalantado of Spaine were here, he should not enter: On, helpe me with the light, Gentlemen: you knocke in vaine sir officer.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Et tu Brute.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sirha close your lips, or I will drop it in thine eyes by heauen.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, O.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Open the dore, or I will breake it open.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay good Constable haue patience a little, you shall come in presently, we haue almost done.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: So; now, are you out of your humor sir. Shift Gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter Constable with Officers, and stay Briske.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Lay hold vpon this gallant, and pursue the rest.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Lay hold on me sir! for what?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Mary for your riot here sir, with the rest of your companions.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: My riot! God's my judge, take heed what you doe; Carlo did I offer any violence?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O sir, you see he is not in case to answere you, & that makes you so paramptorie.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Peremptorie, Shife I appeale to the Drawers, if I did him any hard measure.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: They are all gone, there's none of them will bee laid any hold on.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well sir, you are like to answere till the rest can bee found out.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Sbloud I appeale to George here.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Tut George was not here: away with him to the Counter sirs. Come sir you were best get your selfe drest somewhere.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Good Lord that maister Carlo could not take heed, and knowing what a Gentleman the knight is if he be angrie.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: A poxe on 'hem, they haue left all the meat on our hands, would they were choakt with it for me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What are they gone sirs.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: O here's maister Macilente.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Sirha George do'you see that concealement there? that Napkin vnder the Table?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Gods so', Signior Fungoso!

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Hee's a good pawne for the reckoning; be sure you keepe him here, and let him not goe away till I come againe, though he offer to discharge all; I'le returne presently.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Sirrah, we haue a pawne for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What? of Macilente?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: No; looke vnder the Table.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I hope all be quiet now; if I can get but forth of this street, I care not. Masters, I pray you tell me, is the Constable gone?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: What? Master Fungoso?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Was't not a good deuise the same of me Sirs?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Yes faith; ha' you been here all this while?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: O God I: good sirs looke and the coast be cleere, I'ld faine be going.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: All's cleere Sir, but the Reckoning; and that you must cleare and pay before you goe, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I pay? S'light, I eate not a bit since I came into the house yet.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Why you may when you please sir, 'tis all ready below that was bespoken.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Bespoken? not by me, I hope?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: By you Sir? I know not that: but 'twas for you and your companie, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: My companie? S'lid I was an inuited guest, so I was.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Faith we haue nothing to doe with that Sir, they're all gone but you, and we must be answer'd; that's the short and the long on't.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay, if you will grow to extremities, my Masters, then would this Pot, Cup, and all were in my belly, if I haue a crosse about me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: What, and haue such Apparell? Doe not say so, Signior, that mightily discredits your clothes.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: By Iesu the Taylour had all my money this morning, and yet I must be faine to alter my Sute too: good sirs, let me goe, 'tis Friday night; and in good truth I haue no stomack in the world to eat any thing.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: That's no matter so you pay sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Pay? Gods light, with what conscience can you aske me to pay that I neuer dranke for?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Yes sir, I did see you drinke once.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: By this Cup (which is siluer) but you did not, you doe mee infinite wrong, I look't in the pot once indeed, but I did not drinke.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Well sir, if you can satisfie my Maister, it shall be all one to vs. By and by.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Loose not your selfe now Signior.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Tut sir, you did beare too hard a conceit of me in that, but I will now make my loue to you most transparent, in spight of any dust of suspition, that may bee raised to dimme it: and henceforth since I see it is so against your Humor, I will neuer labour to persuade you.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Why I thanke you Signior, but what's that you tell me may concerne my peace so much?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith sir 'tis thus. Your wiues brother Signior Fungoso, being at supper to night at a Tauerne with a sort of Gallants: there happened some diuision amongst'hem, and he is left in pawne for the Reckoning: now if euer you looke that time shall present you with a happie occasion to doe your wife some gracious and acceptable seruice, take hold of this Opportunitie, and presently go and redeeme him; for being her brother, and his credite so amply engaged as now it is, when shee shall heare (as he cannot himselfe, but hee must out of extremitie report it) that you came and offered your selfe so kindly, and with that respect of his Reputation, Slud the benefit cannot but make hir doat, and grow mad of your affections.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p:
Now by heauen Macilente, I acknowledge my selfe exceedingly indebted to you, by this kind tender of your loue; and I am sorry to remember that I was euer so rude to neglect
a friend of your worth, bring me shoes and a cloke there, I was going to bed if you had not come, what Tauerne is it?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: The Miter sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O; why Fido, my shoes. Good faith it cannot but please her exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Come, I mar'le what peece of nightworke you haue in hand now, that you call for your cloke and your shoes: what, is this your Pandor?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O sweet wife speak lower, I would not he should heare thee for a world—

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Hang him rascall, I cannot abide him for his trecherie, with his wild quicke-set beard there. Whether goe you now with him?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: No whether with him deare wife, I goe alone to a place, from whence I will returne instantly. Good Macilente acquaint not her with it by any meanes, it may come so much the more accepted, frame some other answere, I'le come backe immediately.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Nay, and I be not worthy to know whether you go, stay till I take knowledge of your comming backe.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Heare you mistres Deliro.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: So Sir, and what say you?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith Ladie, my intents will not deserue this slight respect, when you shall know'hem.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Your intents? why, what may your intents be for Gods sake?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Troth the time allows no circumstance Ladie, therfore know, this was but a deuise to remoue your Husband hence, & bestow him securely, whilest (with more conueniencie) I might report to you a misfortune that hath happened to Mounsieur Briske; nay comfort sweet Ladie. This night (being at supper) a sort of young Gallants committed a Riot, for the which hee (onely) is apprehended and caried to the Counter, where if your Husband and other Creditors should but haue knowledge of him, the poore Gentleman were vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Aye me, that he were.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Now therefore, if you can thinke vpon any present meanes for his deliuerie, doe not forslow it. A bribe to the officer that committed him, will doe it.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O God Sir, he shall not want for a bribe: pray you, will you commend me to him, and say I'le visit him presently.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: No Ladie, I shall do you better seruice in protracting your husbands returne, that you may goe with more safetie?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Good truth so you may; farewell good Sir. Lord how a woman may be mistaken in a man? I would haue sworne vpon all the Testaments in the world he had not lou'd maister Briske. Bring me my keyes there maid: Alasse good Gentleman, if all I haue i' this earthly world will pleasure him, it shall bee at his seruice.

sp.speaker: Mitis.
sp.p: How Macilente sweats i' this businesse, if you marke him?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: I, you shall see the true picture of Spight anone, here comes the Pawne and his Redeemer.

div.stage: Enter Deliro, Fungoso, Drawer following them.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Come Brother, be not discourag'd for this man, what?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: No truly, I am not discourag'd, but I protest to you Brother I haue done imitating any more Gallants either in purse or apparrell, but as shall become a Gentleman for good carriage or so.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: You say well. This is all i' the bill here? is't not?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: There's your money, tell it: and Brother, I am glad I met with so good occasion to shew my loue to you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I will studie to deserue it in good truth, and I liue.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: What is't right?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I Sir, and I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Let me haue a Capons legge sau'd, now the reckoning is paid.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: You shall Sir:

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Where's Signior Deliro?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Here Macilente.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Harke you sir, ha' you dispatcht this same?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I marry haue I.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Well then, I can tell you newes, Briske is i' the Counter.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I' the Counter?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: 'Tis true Sir, committed for the stirre here to night. Now would I haue you send your brother home afore, with the report of this your kindnesse done him to his sister, which will so pleasingly possesse her, and out of his mouth too, that i' the meane time you may clap your Action on Briske, and your wife (being in so happie a mood) cannot entertaine it ill by any meanes.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, she cannot indeed, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Thinke? why 'tis past thought, you shall neuer meet the like opportunitie, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I will doe it. Brother pray you go home afore, this Gent. and I haue some priuate businesse; and tell my sweet wife, I'le come presently.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I will Brother.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: And Signior, acquaint your sister, how liberally and out of his bountie, you brother has vs'd you. (Doe you see?) made you a man of good Reckoning; redeem'd that you neuer were possest of, Credite; gaue you as Gentlemanlike terms as might be; found no fault with your comming behind the fashion; nor nothing.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay I am out of those Humors now.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Well, if you be out, keepe your distance, and be not made a Shot-clog no more. Come Signior, let's make hast.

sp.speaker: Fallace.
sp.p: O maister Fastidius, what pittie is't to see so sweet a man as you are, in so soure a place?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: As vpon her lips do's she meane?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, this is to be imagin'd the Counter belike?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Troth faire Ladie, 'tis first the pleasure of the Fates, and next of the Constable to haue it so, but, I am patient, and indeed comforted the more in your kind visitation.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Nay, you shall bee comforted in me more than this, if you please Sir. I sent you word by my Brother Sir, that my husband laid to rest you this morning, I know not whether you receiu'd it, or no?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No beleeue it, sweet Creature, your Brother gaue mee no such intelligence.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O the Lord!

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: But has your husband any such purpose?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O God Maister Briske, yes: and therefore bee presently discharg'd; for if he come with his Actions vpon you (Lord deliuer you) you are in for one halfe a score yeare; he kept a poor man in Ludgate once, twelue year for sixteene shillings. Where's your keeper, for Gods loue call him, let him take a bribe, and dispatch you, Lord how my heart trembles! here are no spies? are there?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No sweet mistresse, why are you in this passion?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O Christ Maister Fastidius, if you knew how I tooke vp my husband to day, when he said he would arrest you; and how I rail'd at him that persuaded him to't, the Scholler there, (who on my conscience loues you now) & what care I tooke to send you intelligence by my Brother; and how I gaue him foure Soueraignes for his paines; and now, how I came running out hether without man or boy with mee, so soone as I heard on't; you'ld say, I were in a Passion indeed: your keeper for Gods sake. O Maister Briske (as 'tis in Euphues) Hard is the choise, when one is compelled either by silence to die with greefe, or by speaking to liue with shame.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
Faire Ladie I conceiue you, and may this kisse assure
you, that where Aduersitie hath (as it were) contracted, Prosperitie shall not— Gods light your Husband.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O mee!

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I? is't thus!

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why how now Signior Deliro? has the Wolfe seene you? ha? hath Gorgons head made marble on you?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Some Planet strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why looke you Sir, I told you, you might haue suspected this long afore, had you pleas'd; and ha' sau'd this labor of Admiration now, and Passion, and such extremities as this fraile lumpe of Flesh is subiect vnto. Nay, why doe you not dote now Signior? Me thinks you should say it were some Enchantment, Deceptio visus, or so, ha? if you could persuade your selfe it were a dreame now, 'twere excellent: faith trie what you can doe Signior; it may bee your Imagination will bee brought to it in time, there's nothing impossible.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Sweet Husband?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Out lasciuious Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: What? did you see how ill that stale vain became him afore, of Sweet Wife, and Deare heart? and are you falne just into the same now? with Sweet Husband. Away, follow him, goe, keepe state, what? Remember you are a woman: turn impudent: gi' him not the head, though you gi' him the horns, Away. Exit Fallace .And yet mee thinkes you should take your leaue of Infans-perdus here, your forlorn hope. How now Mounsieur Brisk: what?
